story:
My name is Josh Schuman and I am 16 years old.  I have always believed in the adage that Knowledge is Power. I hope to raise enough money to buy thesauruses and present them as a gift to a select group of inner city high school kids.

I have already secured permission with a principal in the Newark Public School system to execute this project. My goal is to encourage the kids  to use these thesauruses and challenge them to enter into an essay writing competition that I am conducting. To motivate them, I plan to give out gift cards to the top male and female winners. I am hoping that this experiment/project will excite and spark their interest in learning.

This idea originated when I was in 4th grade. I had received a dictionary from a local Rotary Club. Although I did not know these people personally nor did I know what a Rotary Club was, I often used the dictionary nonetheless. This experience made an indelible impression on me. I hope that I can make more of an impact on these kids by personally gifting them a thesaurus. How often does anybody receive a random gift from a stranger? I hope this will inspire them to enjoy learning the power of words.

Thank you in advance for contributing towards my project.

story:
Who we are


The University of the Western Cape (UWC) is a previously disadvantaged university which was originally established in 1960 as an ethnic college for ‘coloured’ students in Bellville South, Cape Town. Since then, the University has grown substantially, and has seven faculties, comprising of 68 departments and 16 institutes, schools and research centres, carrying out cutting-edge work towards building a better society for all. Drawing on its experience in the liberation struggle, the University has transformed itself from a small Apartheid educational institution to an internationally recognised university with a reputation for excellence in teaching, learning and research. It is also committed to nurturing the cultural diversity of South Africa and responding in critical creative ways to the needs of a society in transition. 

The Cause


From 29 January to 1 February 2015, some of South Africa’s top universities competed in the South African Qualifying Round of the 56th Philip C. Jessup International Law Moot Court Competition, held at the University of the Western Cape, the first time it was held at a historically disadvantaged university in South Africa. In the end, the University of the Western Cape emerged victorious, earning the right to represent South Africa in the international phase of the world’s largest and most prestigious courtroom challenge. 

The Philip C. Jessup International Law Moot Court Competition is a simulation of a fictional dispute between countries before the International Court of Justice (the judicial arm of the United Nations). Student teams prepare oral and written pleadings arguing both the applicant and respondent positions of the case - in this case, the legal battles between the Federal Republic of Agnostica and the State of Reverentia over the fate of East Agnostica (Hypothetical countries.).

This is the first time that a previously disadvantaged university will be representing South Africa at  the International Rounds of the 2015 Philip C. Jessup International Moot Competition to be held in Capitol Hill, Washington D.C. from 5 to 11 April of this year. 

However...


What We Need


We have done some basic research as to the costing, and we estimate that we will require close to $20 000 (Roughly, R200 000) to cover all the prerequisite expenses (this includes flights, accommodation, and subsistence for transport and meals when in Washington). We are doing everything in our power to lower this amount, and we will probably require less if we are able to book flights and accommodation sooner rather than later, but time is of the essence.

Naturally, the above cost implications pose a massive barrier to entry, as the simple truth is that the financial profile of the average UWC student and their family would not allow them to pay for this themselves, and therefore we have endeavoured to raise funds from a variety of sources. Consequently, in addition to this crowd funding initiative, we are contacting a variety of law firms, companies and government institutions to ask for assistance. Every contribution is a step closer to the dream, every bit helps. 


The Impact


One of the common criticisms that the legal fraternity has with regards to recent law graduates is that their skillset is very rarely practically relevant, often resulting in many law students initially struggling with the pace and challenge of legal practice. From participating in moot court competitions law students learn how to research, write and argue the law in both written and oral format, giving them a competitive and academic advantage above other students. Consequently, mooting is an essential tool to educate, develop and transform legal scholars into the best legal practitioners they can be. This then plays an instrumental role in developing the African legal fraternity and producing the finest legal practitioners in Africa. 
As the Philip C. Jessup International Law Moot Court Competition is evidently held in the field of International Law and deals with pressing legal matters in the world today, mooting in this regard also contributes to the international community in general. 

We promise our utmost in this regard and strive to bring the Jessup Cup back home to South Africa. Please consider assisting us in our endeavours. 

We thank you!

story:
Short Summary

We are Jimmy, Kareen, and Megan. We are three graduate students at the University of Southern California in the elementary teaching program, and we are all soon to be teachers. We are hosting this campaign to get us to Science in the Rockies 2013. This is a conference for teachers who want to use hands-on and engaging demonstrations of scientific principles. As incoming first-year teachers, we are passionate about finding ways to improve our teaching practice in order to benefit our students. Imagine if science class was more like the science museum, and less of reading from the textbook? Your contributions would help us achieve our goals.

Find out more about Science at the Rockies here: http://www.stevespanglerscience.com/teacher-tra...

What We Need & What You Get

Details:

  • Registration fee per person: $895 per person
    • Includes $300 worth of science supplies for our classrooms
  • Flights: $350/per person, roundtrip from LAX to DEN
  • Hotel: $900 total for three nights for three people
  • Food and Transportation: Approximately $500
  • Miscellaneous, Tax, etc.: $600
  • Perks: $200-$250

The Impact

Want to know the difference that you will be making?

  • Your contribution will help foster interest in STEM subjects in our future students
  • You are helping to professionally develop three future science educators
  • You are making a concrete and direct change to the education system!

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share our campagign: igg.me/at/trojansattherockies
  • Share our youtube video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eqaZGV16WCk
  • Get the word out!

story:
:: Campaign Update ::

 

As passionate as we are about eliminating debt for those struggling now with repayment, we have been advised by members of Strike Debt that because of the tax implications, we would be causing those that we wish to help more harm than good. However the solution to a debt free future for those in college now and in the future still exists. The crowdfunding model works the same; it’s just the method of eliminating the debt we have to change in order to comply with tax codes.

 

Cash gifts paid directly to educational institutions are not considered taxable gifts, therefore providing an alternative source of funding for students, instead of relying on loans to fund the remainder of the tuition that scholarships and grants couldn’t cover.

The average debt that two thirds of graduating college students accrues now stands at around $27,000. That’s roughly an average of $6,750 every year that students need in loans to accommodate the costs of tuition. We are aware not everyone is directly affected by loans but all college students share a common bond of personal growth and desire. It is that common bond that we are hoping creates solidarity among every college student in America to give $3 to ensure that anyone who desires to pursue their dreams of growth can do so.

 

Our goal is to create a loan resistance of grand proportion by creating solidarity for college students living a debt free existence after their education. The following perks benefit the following number of students:

 

  • $3 joins you and 9999 others in solidarity to remove loans from 4 college students' yearly financial aid package. Debt Free Future
  • $6 joins you and 9999 others in solidarity to remove loans from 8 college students' yearly financial aid package. Debt Free Future
  • $9 joins you and 9999 others in solidarity to remove loans from 13 college students' yearly financial aid package. Debt Free Future
  • $12 joins you and 9999 others in solidarity to remove loans from 17 college students' yearly financial aid package. Debt Free Future
  • $15 joins you and 9999 others in solidarity to remove loans from 22 college students' yearly financial aid package. Debt Free Future
  • $25 is your gift to helping us fund the cost of creating our organization’s structure.

 

Although we are creating our community base and brand awareness here, our goal is to create a nationwide community for commonality among college students and others to the idea of “equity financing” and resistance to loans rather than the traditional debt financing we have dealt with for the past 50 years. With our organization and committed individuals ready to give we could have the new solution to eliminating student debt in colleges across the country for this generation of college students and beyond.

 

Just to put in perspective if every college student in America gave up $3 a week for a year, the 20 million college students who are enrolled at the colleges and universities all over this country together could help eliminate the need for loans for hundreds of thousands of their fellow students every fall.

The big picture will be a generation of educated individuals free from the burden of debt to make career decisions based on passion rather than need. Not to mention the extra money, not used for student debt, can go back into the economy rather than the lenders which could certainly use a boost. What affect will this plan have on college tuition, the student loan lenders, tax payer dollars, economic ramifications are far from being known, however we believe it is a relatively cheap investment for an experiment with a potentially grand outcome.

 

Join the community movement designed to accomplish a community end for the need of student loans.

 Spread the word!

story:
The 16th Strike Documentary

My name is Toni "Alika" Hickman, and I am a young stroke survivor, two brain aneurysms survivor, speaker for the American Heart Association, motivational speaker, hip hop artist with KripHop nation, which is a group of artist with disabilities that travel the world performing and speaking on disability issues. I am also a mother, an activist for minorities, an author, and a poet.

This film is important because as an African living in America, I see that we suffer many pains as a people. We carry the angers of our past on our shoulders, and it reflects in our dealings with each other, our foods and how we eat, and our violence toward one another.

When you contribute to this film, you are actually helping create change in the world. Every race knows of the pains we as a people carry, but we have the potential to be great. This documentary tackles our flaws, but also goes through the steps to correct them.



What We Need & What You Get

In order to get the maximum exposure for a film as potent as this, we need publicity, marketing and promotional materials, The cases, DVDs, Graphics, and printing.We also need distributors.At the lower end of it all, it estimates to about $35,000 dollars.

We are doing give aways,  putting some peoples name in the Documentary depending on contribution amount, offering specialties and more!

Even if by some chance our financial goal is not met, we will still award those that have helped through listing their names in documentary and possible specialties depending on finances available.But the listing in the documentary will defenitely be available.

The Impact

Blacks/Africans in America are going through a serious issue, and we are dying by the case! This DocumentaryIs so needed in the African American community. You really are helping change our world when you contribute to this film.
 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't donate anything, you can help by spreading the word, passing our link along, and telling others about contributing. All of your efforts are appreciated, as this film will be a positive wake up for all Africans in America.

All we need from you is to use the indiegogo Share tools! Thank you so much!!

story:
Summary

My name is Natalie Pena, and I am currently a graduating senior at the University of New Mexico's Anderson School of Management. Throughout my journey, I have been guided by various mentors and advisors. They have all had a vested interest in my accomplishments and achievements and have continually supported my efforts to become the best possible leader for my community. With that said, I was invited to attend a leadership training that changed my life and will change our community.

With that said, a group of women are in the process of developing a training for young high school girls to engage in the training as well. However, we cannot support these young ladies until we attend all of the leadership trainings and become a coach. Being a coach will allow us to train women and young women into leadership roles. This is a wonderful opportunity for the community, university, and high school students. If you support our vision, you will directly transform our community. 

What We Need & What You Get

In order to take the training to become a coach and start transforming our community, we are commited to raise the money. The cost of the three month training is 1,200 per person. Our goal is to sponsor four women. Throughout the training, we will build relationships with people who can support our effort of training high school girls.

 

Furthermore, throughout the training will dive deeper into becoming a leadership coach. This will allow us to support the young girls who attend the training. In turn, you will get a deeper insight to the possibilities of transformational leadership and a person who is dedicated to transforming the community. 

 

 

The Impact

Transformational leadership uses positivism to transform teams, groups, and communities. Through the use of inspiration, transformational leaders can support team members by focusing on continued motivation. Furthermore, transformational leadership coaches encourage and support a persons desire to be the best possible leader they can be. It is through a coaches commitment that transformational leadership is sustainable and possible. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Understand the significance and importance of this work by reading articles on transformational leadership.

story:
So Who Am I and What's This Campaign All About

  • Background:

My name is Anastasia Somoza and I am 29 years old and my home town is New York City.  Since graduating from Georgetown University with a BA in Government, I have been unable to find a job outside of unpaid internships.  An extraordinary opportunity is paving the way for me to enjoy a productive and exciting career. In 2011, I received a full scholarship to read for my Master's degree in Human Rights at the London School of Economics and Political Science (LSE) a two year program.  

Here's a little background. Throughout my life, my mother has had to fight to get an education for me and for my twin sister Alba, who is also significantly disabled with cerebral palsy. The greatest battle was with the public schools, where we fought to attend regular classes rather than be relegated to special education classes, which at that time amounted to little more than warehousing for students with special needs.    

In New York City, Medicaid pays for my aide full time, even if I sit home watching television all day. Through a Medicaid waiver, I was able to provide funding for an aide to help me during my time at Georgetown University. However, the story changes when financing is needed to support an aide during study overseas. Medicaid will no longer fund any student's aide outside of New York.

Since last year, my mother and I have worked on legislation that would allow students accepted by an institution of higher learning to take their aide with them while in school. Following my acceptance by LSE, we worked closely with the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services on securing a waiver that would enable my aide to accompany me to London. But just two days before our flight to Heathrow, we received a call denying us that waiver.  

Refusing to Give Up on My Dream 

  • Off to London I Went: 

Already having purchased tickets my mom, sister and I arrived at LSE anyway. We tried and failed to secure funding, but at the 11th hour a friend offered to fund an aide for two months while we tried to fundraise.   An aide came to help me, but it did not work out and she returned abruptly to the U.S.   I had no choice but to come back, seek a deferment of my scholarship, and continue with the fundraising in the hopes of returning in September 2012.

I was devastated to have to leave LSE. Equally significant to the obstacle I faced in being able to overcome the personal care challenges that had occurred, was the inaccessibility of the LSE residence. It was impossible for me to get to my room independently. I had to go through three large fire doors that I could not open on my own. The door to my room was also not automatic and these were just two of many accessibility related details overlooked when I was advised to live in this particular LSE residential hall. Sadly, the room was as far from appropriate or wheelchair-user friendly as it could have been.

The silver lining in the cloud was the involvement of an Emeritus member of the Board of Governors helping me reach an agreement with the school administration to effect some important changes. The meeting was great!  The LSE agreed to make significant accessibility changes to their residences, fund a room for my aides, and work with SCOPE (England's equivalent to United Cerebral Palsy) to make the LSE fully accessible to the extent possible for all students with disabilities.

...And so back home New York City, the fundraiser for the 1st year of care was launched!

LSE, HUMAN RIGHTS and Me are Meant to BE

  • The Result: 

Well, I am incredibly happy to report that through the tireless efforts of friends and family, we raised enough money for me to return to London for this initial year and have 3 community service volunteers funded to assist me with daily living needs!  Not only that, but on arrival, the London School of Economics had completely overhauled the rooms on the ground floor of our residence at Grosvenor House to provide totally accessible rooms for students with disabilities!   I am so thankful to all the people who made this happen.   The rooms are now world class, and compliant with codes. Bottom line, my second time has been a charm: LSE has been great, and absolutely willing to improve things for students with disabilities in any way they can!!

Living abroad, attending a world renowned institution, while adjusting to a new academic system and everything else that comes along with a life changing opportunity such as this, has been both a dream and a privilege! I'm always reminded that life isn't easy and that no goal is worth aspiring to and achieving without sometimes struggling and fighting for it. This journey at LSE is no different. I have faced familiar and unanticipated challenges but with endless hours of hard work, giving everything my best effort and an  enormous amount of support from many,  I have learned a great deal, made the most of this amazing opportunity and successfully completed my first year!

What We Need 

This campaign page is the second round of the fundraising effort for the second year of care!!

So ALL funds raised on this page (and 1 or 2 more campaigns to follow) will cover the  cost of funding 3 Community Service Volunteers (CSVs) to assist me.  The approximate cost  is $15,000 for the upcoming year, per volunteer (including care coverage for 2 or 3 more months than I required the first year, as I will need to be at LSE through the end of NEXT SUMMER, 2014, to complete my dissertation).   British law only allows the volunteers to work a certain number of hours. As such, I will need roughly $50,000 to return next year, finish my degree and it will be because of the generosity of family, friends potential sponsors and other supporters, that I will become a MASTER in Human Rights!!

What You Get

I pledge to continue being a dedicated and hardworking student, and, as a graduate, to go out into the world at large and help improve conditions for others like myself.

I will post updates on the site on a regular basis to let you all know how it is going over here, and hopefully I can effect more changes for students with disabilities along the way.  Please understand that this is a situation where every little bit really will help! I shall be sincerely grateful for any financial assistance from friends, family, and members of the public. I promise to show my immense appreciation and gratitude to every single donor/supporter/word-spreading/sponsor-getting ambassador with boatloads of hugs,  phone calls and/or a personalized "THANK YOU" email depending on how near or far you are!!!!!!!!

The Impact

It's my firm belief that the impact of our campaign will lead to an awareness of the obstacles that people with disabilities face when trying to access higher education. If any non-disabled student received the type of wonderful scholarship opportunity that I have, he/she would not have to decline the offer because of the need for a personal-care aide. My mother and I continue our work together on legislation that will enable students with any disability that necessitates personal-care assistance to take their aide with them if they are enrolled at an institution of higher education. Long-term, this legislation will help people with disabilities to reach their maximum potential and have a better shot at becoming employed. It will also get them off social services and help them to become independent and enjoy a better quality of life.

Other Ways You Can Help

Donations from friends, family, associates and the public at large will, of course, be the greatest help. Additionally, I ask each of you to become an ambassador for my campaign. Please spread the word among your own circle of friends and contacts through Facebook and other social-media channels. This will rapidly build awareness, and will truly help me reach my fundraising goal. And of course, outreach to local media contacts you may have can also help tremendously in getting the message out.  We are also looking into the possibility of a corporate sponsor funding one community service volunteer.  So, if you have any contacts or know of corporations that provide grants to people with disabilities, please let me and my family know

***REMEMBER EVERY LITTLE BIT COUNTS*** I am hoping that you will all help me get the word out in any way you can. Thank you for believing in me, for all your effort and support in encouraging me to continue overcoming adversity in pursuit of my goals and dreams, and most importantly for never allowing me to give up no matter what the odds!!
story_txt:
So Who Am I and What's This Campaign All About

Background:

My name is Anastasia Somoza and I am 29 years old and my home town is New York City.  Since graduating from Georgetown University with a BA in Government, I have been unable to find a job outside of unpaid internships.  An extraordinary opportunity is paving the way for me to enjoy a productive and exciting career. In 2011, I received a full scholarship to read for my Master's degree in Human Rights at the London School of Economics and Political Science (LSE) a two year program.  
Here's a little background. Throughout my life, my mother has had to fight to get an education for me and for my twin sister Alba, who is also significantly disabled with cerebral palsy. The greatest battle was with the public schools, where we fought to attend regular classes rather than be relegated to special education classes, which at that time amounted to little more than warehousing for students with special needs.    
In New York City, Medicaid pays for my aide full time, even if I sit home watching television all day. Through a Medicaid waiver, I was able to provide funding for an aide to help me during my time at Georgetown University. However, the story changes when financing is needed to support an aide during study overseas. Medicaid will no longer fund any student's aide outside of New York.
Since last year, my mother and I have worked on legislation that would allow students accepted by an institution of higher learning to take their aide with them while in school. Following my acceptance by LSE, we worked closely with the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services on securing a waiver that would enable my aide to accompany me to London. But just two days before our flight to Heathrow, we received a call denying us that waiver.  
Refusing to Give Up on My Dream 

Off to London I Went: 

Already having purchased tickets my mom, sister and I arrived at LSE anyway. We tried and failed to secure funding, but at the 11th hour a friend offered to fund an aide for two months while we tried to fundraise.   An aide came to help me, but it did not work out and she returned abruptly to the U.S.   I had no choice but to come back, seek a deferment of my scholarship, and continue with the fundraising in the hopes of returning in September 2012.
I was devastated to have to leave LSE. Equally significant to the obstacle I faced in being able to overcome the personal care challenges that had occurred, was the inaccessibility of the LSE residence. It was impossible for me to get to my room independently. I had to go through three large fire doors that I could not open on my own. The door to my room was also not automatic and these were just two of many accessibility related details overlooked when I was advised to live in this particular LSE residential hall. Sadly, the room was as far from appropriate or wheelchair-user friendly as it could have been.
The silver lining in the cloud was the involvement of an Emeritus member of the Board of Governors helping me reach an agreement with the school administration to effect some important changes. The meeting was great!  The LSE agreed to make significant accessibility changes to their residences, fund a room for my aides, and work with SCOPE (England's equivalent to United Cerebral Palsy) to make the LSE fully accessible to the extent possible for all students with disabilities.
...And so back home New York City, the fundraiser for the 1st year of care was launched!
LSE, HUMAN RIGHTS and Me are Meant to BE

The Result: 

Well, I am incredibly happy to report that through the tireless efforts of friends and family, we raised enough money for me to return to London for this initial year and have 3 community service volunteers funded to assist me with daily living needs!  Not only that, but on arrival, the London School of Economics had completely overhauled the rooms on the ground floor of our residence at Grosvenor House to provide totally accessible rooms for students with disabilities!   I am so thankful to all the people who made this happen.   The rooms are now world class, and compliant with codes. Bottom line, my second time has been a charm: LSE has been great, and absolutely willing to improve things for students with disabilities in any way they can!!
Living abroad, attending a world renowned institution, while adjusting to a new academic system and everything else that comes along with a life changing opportunity such as this, has been both a dream and a privilege! I'm always reminded that life isn't easy and that no goal is worth aspiring to and achieving without sometimes struggling and fighting for it. This journey at LSE is no different. I have faced familiar and unanticipated challenges but with endless hours of hard work, giving everything my best effort and an  enormous amount of support from many,  I have learned a great deal, made the most of this amazing opportunity and successfully completed my first year!
What We Need 
This campaign page is the second round of the fundraising effort for the second year of care!!
So ALL funds raised on this page (and 1 or 2 more campaigns to follow) will cover the  cost of funding 3 Community Service Volunteers (CSVs) to assist me.  The approximate cost  is $15,000 for the upcoming year, per volunteer (including care coverage for 2 or 3 more months than I required the first year, as I will need to be at LSE through the end of NEXT SUMMER, 2014, to complete my dissertation).   British law only allows the volunteers to work a certain number of hours. As such, I will need roughly $50,000 to return next year, finish my degree and it will be because of the generosity of family, friends potential sponsors and other supporters, that I will become a MASTER in Human Rights!!
What You Get
I pledge to continue being a dedicated and hardworking student, and, as a graduate, to go out into the world at large and help improve conditions for others like myself.
I will post updates on the site on a regular basis to let you all know how it is going over here, and hopefully I can effect more changes for students with disabilities along the way.  Please understand that this is a situation where every little bit really will help! I shall be sincerely grateful for any financial assistance from friends, family, and members of the public. I promise to show my immense appreciation and gratitude to every single donor/supporter/word-spreading/sponsor-getting ambassador with boatloads of hugs,  phone calls and/or a personalized "THANK YOU" email depending on how near or far you are!!!!!!!!


The Impact



It's my firm belief that the impact of our campaign will lead to an awareness of the obstacles that people with disabilities face when trying to access higher education. If any non-disabled student received the type of wonderful scholarship opportunity that I have, he/she would not have to decline the offer because of the need for a personal-care aide. My mother and I continue our work together on legislation that will enable students with any disability that necessitates personal-care assistance to take their aide with them if they are enrolled at an institution of higher education. Long-term, this legislation will help people with disabilities to reach their maximum potential and have a better shot at becoming employed. It will also get them off social services and help them to become independent and enjoy a better quality of life.
Other Ways You Can Help
Donations from friends, family, associates and the public at large will, of course, be the greatest help. Additionally, I ask each of you to become an ambassador for my campaign. Please spread the word among your own circle of friends and contacts through Facebook and other social-media channels. This will rapidly build awareness, and will truly help me reach my fundraising goal. And of course, outreach to local media contacts you may have can also help tremendously in getting the message out.  We are also looking into the possibility of a corporate sponsor funding one community service volunteer.  So, if you have any contacts or know of corporations that provide grants to people with disabilities, please let me and my family know
***REMEMBER EVERY LITTLE BIT COUNTS*** I am hoping that you will all help me get the word out in any way you can. Thank you for believing in me, for all your effort and support in encouraging me to continue overcoming adversity in pursuit of my goals and dreams, and most importantly for never allowing me to give up no matter what the odds!!

story:
I studied abroad.  You probably did, too, or know someone who did. 

Studying abroad was a transformative experience for me, igniting my curiousity and my confidence. I learned about myself and the world.

Did you know that community college students make up half of the nation’s undergraduates but only 2% of US students studying abroad?

For my dissertation, I’m doing a case study of a community college study abroad program, so that more community college students will have this transformative learning experience.

Your donation will help offset the costs of my research.

These costs include:

  • My donation to students’ program fees
  • Digital recorder for interviews
  • Transcriptions of my interviews with students
  • Homestay in Peru

Help me get the word out by posting this to Facebook and Twitter.

Many students going on this trip have never left Philly. Thank you for helping open this door for community college students.

story:
Story Shifters is a theatre arts residency specifically designed for students with medical, physical, and neurological impairments, including students on the autism spectrum and students with special needs.

The goal of the program is to build literacy, fluency, and comprehension through drama and social interaction.  Story Shfiters was created in 2011 by Kimberly Strafford, Director of Education and Outreach for kef theatrical productions.  Since then, we have completed four residencies within the NYC public school special education district 75.

In August, we are also launching our new Shifting Shakespeare, a summer residency that provides a creative and nurturing environment where neuro-typical actors collaborate with actors with specials needs to tackle the work of William Shakespeare.

Our goal is to grow more residencies within public schools, as well as private ones, after school programs, and treatment facilities.  With your help, we will continue to offer these residencies free of charge.

In 2013, we are looking to expand our capabilities to support students of varying physical and neurological impairments, by investing in varying speech therapy and communication devices. 

Over the past two years, Story Shifters has received some great feedback from administrators, parents, and students alike.

A principal in the New York City public school system says, "We are so appreciative of your work with our students and staff. They have enjoyed every moment."

One assistant principal had this to say about the Story Shifters program. "I cannot tell you how amazed and impressed I am each semester with the level of language, engagement, and excitement your program elicits from our students."

And one parent said, "I feel like I just saw my son on Broadway."

Story Shifters is a kef productions education and outreach program.

story:
The Practising the Piano Online Academy has launched!

After over six months of hard work, I am delighted to officially announce the launch of the Practising the Piano Online Academy at https://online-academy.informance.biz. We'd like to take this opportunity to express my heartfelt thanks to everyone who supported the crowdfunding campaign prior to launch. The Online Academy wouldn’t have been possible without your support and we very much appreciate your vote of confidence in the project!

Although it has been an interesting journey over the last few months, the launch of the Online Academy is only the beginning. With the site now up and running, we will be extending, updating and refining its content on a continuous basis (please click here to find out more about the content what we’re currently working on). We’ll also be giving our subscribers regular opportunities to provide feedback and input so that we can shape the content according to your needs.

Please click here to find out more or click here to visit the site, view free content and subscribe.

The story so far... 

Hello, I'm Graham Fitch and I'm  passionate about teaching and playing the piano. The art of practising is a special area of interest to me and is rarely taught specifically enough. Our practice time at the piano is just as significant to the end product as the hours of training undertaken by professional athletes, but this time can so easily be wasted unless we have the know-how.  Effective practice is essential to mastering the piano and it’s for this reason that I have spent decades researching and experimenting in the art of practising to find the optimal approaches.

I’ve developed a methodology comprising practice tools, strategies and techniques which have been tried and tested by students of all ages and levels of ability.  I would love to see as many people as possible benefit from my work.  Therefore I have embarked upon a number of initiatives in order to make my work more widely accessible for those who cannot get to me for one-to-one lessons:

  • My blog (www.practisingthepiano.com) which is regularly updated and contains hundreds of articles on subjects relating to piano playing
  • A Multimedia eBook series which combines text, video, audio and numerous musical examples to introduce my methodology and approach
  • A print version of my eBook series which is currently being developed due to popular demand

My blog and eBooks provide a conceptual introduction to my approach and I am now seeking your support to build on these foundations and take my work to the next level with my new initiative, the Practising the Piano Online Academy.

What is it?

The Practising the Piano Online Academy  is an extensive, searchable, and regularly updated library of lessons, articles and resources which will:

  • Illustrate my methodologies and approach in more depth with multimedia content, interactive features and resources such as musical examples, worksheets and annotated scores which can be downloaded and printed.
  • Expand on practice tools and strategies with masterclasses and tutorials applying them to popular pieces in the repertoire, exam syllabuses and specific technical challenges.
  • Share the expertise of guest experts on subjects including applied theory, improvisation and healthy piano playing.
  • Be regularly updated, easily searchable and allow for personalisation with bookmarking and notes.
  • Be shaped by your input, responding to your questions and suggestions for new content to meet your needs.

Features & examples

The Practising the Piano Online Academy will feature numerous lessons, articles, masterclasses and tutorials which can be navigated and searched by topics, sub topics, tags and key words:

Subscribers will be able to submit and vote for topics and content to be featured:

There will also be resources which can be downloaded and printed for use at the keyboard or in lessons:


Please visit the "gallery" tab above for additional images and screenshots.  A demo site featuring sample content is also available here.

What it will do for you?

Whether you are a budding student, keen amateur, passionate piano teacher or a professional musician, the Practising the Piano Online Academy will provide you with the knowledge and resources at your finger-tips to:

  • Get the best possible results from your time spent practising the piano.
  • Avoid injury and overcome technical difficulties with panache.
  • Learn new pieces quickly and master trouble spots or challenging areas within the repertoire.
  • Deliver performances or achieve examination results which reflect your full potential.
  • Inspire your students and enhance their enjoyment of the piano.

How you can get involved?

We’ve already started creating content for this project and are now seeking your support to make this resource as good as it can possibly be. We're offering you the opportunity to benefit from a number of special offers and unique rewards by pledging your support for our crowdfunding campaign. These include: 

  • A taster subscription as an easy, cost effective way to obtain access to content and show your support.
  • Early-bird offers and discounted annual subscriptions.
  • VIP perks such as sponsoring topics and one-to-one Skype consultations with Graham. 
All of your contributions will go directly towards creating content for the Practising the Piano Online Academy. You will also have an opportunity to shape the development of this resource by suggesting and voting for topics and content you would like to see featured. With your support and input, we are confident that we will create what will become an indispensable resource to you.    

Please help us spread the word by sharing this project with anyone who you think may be interested.  

Thank you in advance for your support!

Icons made by Freepik and 
Visual Pharm 
from www.flaticon.com

story:
Rebuilding Nepal

Simply put, Nepali will use what they know and rebuild their village structures with the same masonry concepts which allowed them to collapse. 

So, why are we doing this?

  • We have been teaching vocation education in Haiti for 6 years through www.globalgroundwork.org in an effort to enable Haitians to rebuild Haiti.
  • We do not want to see the same mistakes implemented in Haiti repeated in Nepal. We have witnessed many good intentioned people attempt to implement their 'good idea' in response to the earthquake in Haiti. Most of these concepts did not take into consideration local culture, local income, or local materials,  and also took focus away from proper solutions for the immediate needs.
  • We have a Facebook group of over 60 engineers, masons, builders all working toward a simple solution. We asked a question of the originator of Ubuntublox on what he thought could be done to easily strengthen existing village masonry against seismic forces, and from that initial discussion the Facebook group was formed. https://www.facebook.com/groups/1426280444347430/
  • One village will begin live testing the concept, we are also building one here in the US for additional testing.
  • Solution will be open-source, all materials we create will be available to anyone.
We seek funding to:

1. Finish creating the education materials which includes:
  • Short demo video (currently being worked on by volunteers)
  • A step by step drawing on laminated sheets showing a simple addition to their traditional masonry techniques which will provide seismic resilience.
  • Production of test buildings
2. Implementation of our logistical plan to promote the concept at the village level.

3. Continue to provide basic aid as needed.

The Impact:

Nepali will rebuild, they are a resilient. They have found temporary solutions, from tin shacks to tarps and tents.

  • Others are promoting temporary solutions, or solutions which have a cost over the yearly income for a family.
  • We have built earthquake resistant structures out of garbage, organic material, and now masonry. Here is the shake testing from the garbage structure: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ex6bJ_0oShg


Challenges:

There are over 4200 village districts within Nepal, at varied elevations. Not all are affected by damage from the two major quakes. Logistics will be our greatest challenge


Other Ways You Can Help

Are you a mason? In Nepal? Maybe we can use your assistance

story:
**** READ IN ENGLISH ****

the iRegular project  te ayuda a aprender los verbos irregulares en inglés de una manera visual e interactiva. 

Descargar versión beta Android(solo 16 verbos) | video demo app 

La historia

Si quieres conocer la historia completa: TEDx sobre the iRegular project

“Hace tres años mi nivel de inglés era muy bajo y decidí apuntarme a clases de inglés. Me costaba mucho memorizar el vocabulario, sobre todo ¡los dichosos verbos irregulares! Como soy diseñadora empecé a diseñar y dibujar los verbos irregulares. Así descubrí que gracias a este componente visual ¡los recordaba! Y si esto me facilitaba a mí el estudio de la gramática inglesa… ¿por qué no acercarlo a más personas? Así nació the iRegular project.

Grabé un vídeo compartiendo la idea. Allí, pedía a diseñadores y programadores que se unieran al proyecto con el fin de desarrollar una aplicación visual e interactiva que facilitara el estudio de los verbos irregulares en inglés. 

A los pocos días de colgar el vídeo, ya contaba con más 100 peticiones de artistas de todo el mundo que querían unirse al movimiento iRegular de forma altruista. Fue increíble y eso me hizo pensar que las ideas que nacen del corazón atraen a muchas  buenas personas."

Inés Arroyo, founder at todaunadama creative studio

---

Gracias a la profesionalidad y colaboración de estos artistas, pudimos lanzar en el 2012 la primera versión de the iRegular project con 54 verbos, disponible en formato iPad. A los pocos meses, la aplicación se convirtió en nº1 de la categoría educativa de la AppStore.

Todo este trabajo  se ha desarrollado gracias a la colaboración altruista de más de 100 profesionales durante dos años y medio. Ahora tenemos más de 130 verbos irregulares diseñados que esperan ser implementados ¡por eso necesitamos tu ayuda!

¡Colabora para que podamos desarrollar una aplicación completa para Android e iOS!

¿Qué queremos? 

Hacer the iRegular project accesible para el mayor número de gente posible. Queremos crear una aplicación disponible para iOS y Android con los 154 verbos irregulares en inglés con traducción de la aplicación a los ocho idiomas más hablados en el mundo. 

¿Cómo se va a distribuir este dinero?

Esta cantidad nos daría para desarrollar la base de la app y un numero limitado de verbos y funcionalidades, pero nos gustaría poder llegar a mas :)


¿Y si conseguimos menos dinero del objetivo marcado?

Si conseguimos menos importe, haremos todo lo posible para poner la infraestructura de la app y desarrollaremos el número de verbos que el importe recaudado nos permita llegar.

¿Por qué participar en nuestra campaña?

Gracias a la tecnología y a las nuevas herramientas digitales, la forma de educar y de aprender ha cambiado. La interactividad y la colaboración en red son fundamentales. Desde the iRegular project fomentamos estos valores. Queremos seguir desarrollando nuevas técnicas de aprendizaje vinculadas al diseño, tecnología y educación. ¡COLABORA!

Si no puedes colaborar económicamente

  1. Comparte este link

  2. ¿Eres desarrollador de apps? Colabora con tu tiempo de desarrollo.

  3. Educa y enseña desde el amor y el cariño, así crearemos una sociedad mejor

Testimonios

"Doy clases Inglés a chavales de bachillerato usando diferentes metodologías. Les dije que aprenderíamos los verbos de una forma diferente. 117 niños de entre 11 y 17 años dibujaron sus verbos favoritos. En el examen sobre verbos irregulares, te puedo decir que hubo más de un 95% de aprobados. Quiero que sepais que es mi intención difundir esta idea en todos los centros educativos que pueda y esto lo hago cómo agradecimiento por la inspiración que nos habeis dado con vuestro proyecto." "

Gerardo Machado, Fundador del proyecto‘Play as Kids’

Premios y menciones

Recompensas


----ENGLISH VERSION ---- 

the iRegular project helps you learn English irregular verbs in a visual and easy way.

Download Android beta version (only 16 verbs) video demo app 


The Story

Would you like to know the complete story? TEDx about the iRegular project

“Three years ago, my English level was quite low so I decided to sign up for English classes. I realized that one of the most difficult things for me was to memorize the vocabulary, especially all the irregular verbs. Almost intuitively, and because of my designer background, I started to draw those verbs using various elements. I then discovered that, thanks to this visual component, I remembered them much better. That helped me to better study English grammar. Why wouldn’t I want to share this with other people? That’s how the iRegular Project was born.

I filmed a video to share the idea.  In the video, I asked designers and programmers to take part in the project and develop a visual and interactive application that would make studying the English irregular verbs easier".

Inés Arroyo, founder at todaunadama creative studio

Just a few days after uploading the video, more than 100 artists from around the world had already responded and wanted to join the iRegular movement altruistically. It was so exciting!

Thanks to the professionalism and collaboration of these artists, we were able to launch the first version of the iRegular Project in 2012 with 54 verbs for the iPad. A few months later, our application became Nº1 App in the AppStore’s education category.

We want to keep growing! That’s why we’ve launched this Crowdfunding campaign. Our goal is for the iRegular Project App, which already has 120 designed and animated verbs, to be available for iPad and Android mobile devices.

Do you want to take part in this movement that joins design, technology and education? Contribute to the iRegular Project!  

What do we want to do? 

Make the iRegular project available to everyone!

To do so, we need to create an application for both iOS and Android with 154 irregular English verbs translated into the eight most-spoken languages in the world. 

How will this money be invested?

This amount will be enough to put the basis for the app and a limited number of verbs and features. However, we’d like to achieve more

What happens if we receive less than our target goal?

If we get less amount,  we’ll develop as many verbs as possible according to the resources available.

Why contributing to the iRegular Project?

We’ve developed and tested this learning technique that unites design, technology and education.

We feel that a lot of the current educational content has become quite obsolete and we can update it thanks to the new digital tools. However, the most important thing is to teach with affection and love.

Thanks to technology and new digital tools, the way to both teach and learn has changed. Interaction and collaboration on the Internet are fundamental. Here at the iRegular Project, we encourage these values. We want to continue to develop new learning techniques linked to design, technology and education. Support us!

Don’t worry if you can't collaborate economically:

  1. Share this link.

  2. Are you an App developer for iOS and Android? Collaborate with your time and talent and help us develop the App.

  3. Educate and teach with affection and love. We’ll create a better society!
Testimonies

“I teach Biology and English at High school and I use various methods. I told my students we were going to learn English irregular verbs in a different way. 117 kids between 11 and 17 years old drew their preferred verbs and on the exam, 95% passed!” 

Gerardo Machado, Founder at ‘Play as Kids’

Adwards and mentions

Perks

**** READ IN ENGLISH ****


the iRegular project  te ayuda a aprender los verbos irregulares en inglés de una manera visual e interactiva. 


Descargar versión beta Android(solo 16 verbos) | video demo app 



La historia
Si quieres conocer la historia completa: TEDx sobre the iRegular project



“Hace tres años mi nivel de inglés era muy bajo y decidí apuntarme a clases de inglés. Me costaba mucho memorizar el vocabulario, sobre todo ¡los dichosos verbos irregulares! Como soy diseñadora empecé a diseñar y dibujar los verbos irregulares. Así descubrí que gracias a este componente visual ¡los recordaba! Y si esto me facilitaba a mí el estudio de la gramática inglesa… ¿por qué no acercarlo a más personas? Así nació the iRegular project.




Grabé un vídeo compartiendo la idea. Allí, pedía a diseñadores y programadores que se unieran al proyecto con el fin de desarrollar una aplicación visual e interactiva que facilitara el estudio de los verbos irregulares en inglés. 
A los pocos días de colgar el vídeo, ya contaba con más 100 peticiones de artistas de todo el mundo que querían unirse al movimiento iRegular de forma altruista. Fue increíble y eso me hizo pensar que las ideas que nacen del corazón atraen a muchas  buenas personas."

Inés Arroyo, founder at todaunadama creative studio
---
Gracias a la profesionalidad y colaboración de estos artistas, pudimos lanzar en el 2012 la primera versión de the iRegular project con 54 verbos, disponible en formato iPad. A los pocos meses, la aplicación se convirtió en nº1 de la categoría educativa de la AppStore.



Todo este trabajo  se ha desarrollado gracias a la colaboración altruista de más de 100 profesionales durante dos años y medio. Ahora tenemos más de 130 verbos irregulares diseñados que esperan ser implementados ¡por eso necesitamos tu ayuda!

Hacer the iRegular project accesible para el mayor número de gente posible. Queremos crear una aplicación disponible para iOS y Android con los 154 verbos irregulares en inglés con traducción de la aplicación a los ocho idiomas más hablados en el mundo.

Gracias a la tecnología y a las nuevas herramientas digitales, la forma de educar y de aprender ha cambiado. La interactividad y la colaboración en red son fundamentales. story:
What is this campaign about?

Hello, My name is Christopher Jilley. A very good friend of mine David Burrows and I have visited Thailand, Laos and SE Asia a number of times and have ridden around much of Thailand and Laos by Motorcycle. During our visit's we have always been overwhelmed by the warmth and love of the people of Laos. Given the hardship and loss the country and its people have and still do endure, the love and friendship the Laos people are so willing to share is so Inspiring. 

The children of Laos want so much to learn and some travel long distances to attend schools with very little equipment to assist in their learning other than of course the vital support provided by the devoted families and teachers, many of whom are volunteers.

We realise that we can only do a little, but a little goes a very long way! Last year through the generosity of others we raised funds through our workplaces, friends, online and our own contributions to raise funds to purchase school equipment as well as bicycles and helmets to give to schools to help their students get to school where no public transport is available or can be afforded.

Feel free to check out our Blog http://illyjay.blogspot.com.au/ where you can see the difference your help can make. 

We invite you to join us on our next adventure where we will again visit the children of Laos to give them some extra tools to assist in their development. From November 1st 2013 to November 20th 2014 we will be riding around these beautiful countries, bringing a book party to a School as well as giving out books to many others along the way, the more you can help, the more we can do :)

If you are able to and willing to support us in this good cause we promise you it will make a significant difference to the lives of many Laotians!

We will of course post receipts for the purchases with 100% of the money raised going directly to the people of Laos in the form of School Equipment. 

See the bottom of this page for links to organisations that inspired us that support the Laos people from education to clearing UXO (Unexploded Ordinance)

What We Need & What You Get

We would love to be able to purchase more equipment for these kids and with your help we can do just that!

You will get the opportunity to follow us on our motorcycle adventure through these beautiful lands and get to share in the joy of helping many children in their development. http://illyjay.blogspot.com.au/

The Impact

Providing Children tools and opportunities they may otherwise not have in their development.

Improving the potential for this beautiful country and its people for generations to come by further investing in education.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this campaign with as many as you can, a little goes a long way, a little from alot goes a very long way :)

If you are able to, support other charities and good cause organisations working to help others. Use the links below to learn more about some of these organisations.

Momo Books (Language Learning Resources) - http://www.momobooks.org/

MAG (Mines Advisory Group) - http://www.maginternational.org/

Why not visit Laos or Thailand for your next trip abroad? Such amazing places to see and people to meet :) Kop Jai Lai Lai or Kop Kuhn Kup (Thank you very much)

story:
As you can see we have already had very generous donors, but the fact is the need on La Gonave was always going to exceed our goal. While the campaign is still open please consider helping us exceed our goal so many more children can benefit as well. Remember, everything I collect will go directly to feed children with malnutrition. Every donation, no matter how small, makes a big difference.
Short Summary

My name is Cole Honeycutt. I'm a rising junior in high school in Chapel Hill, North Carolina. Last year, I took a global issues class that looked at the country of Haiti and the problems there that have presented themselves. In June of this year, I traveled to Haiti to work in La Gonave, a remote, rural island off the coast of Haiti, with the La Gonave Haiti Partnership. The Partnership focuses on many aspects of health in La Gonave, but the aspect I was really struck by was the Medika Mamba program. Medika Mamba is a program that has created a peanut-based paste called "Plumpy Nut", which they use to treat severe malnutrition. This paste is packed full of nutrients necessary to rapidly bring the children back to normal body weight. The La Gonave Haiti Partnership closely monitors the weight and growth of kids who are entered into the program. I saw many of these children in the clinic in La Gonave and heard stories from parents about how Medika Mamba saved their children's lives. These experiences were what truly inspired me to do this. The cost to enter a single child into the program and for them to receive adequate treatment is a mere $90. Therefore, it goes without saying that any donation could potentially have a life-changing impact on an individual. 

What We Need & What You Get

My goal is to raise $9,000 USD for the Medika Mamba program of the La Gonave Haiti Partnership. All funds will go specifically to the cost of entering children into this program. All donations are tax-deductible since the La Gonave Haiti Partnership is a non-profit organization. 

The Impact

To put it simply, Haiti has endured incredible hardship throughout their history. From earthquakes to political unrest to socioeconomic exploitation by other countries, the people of Haiti have suffered greatly over the last century. La Gonave has suffered even more greatly than mainland Haiti. The levels of rural poverty and misfortune there seemed much greater to me and malnutrition was very common. If we reach our goal, it will allow the La Gonave Haiti Partnership to treat another 100 severely malnourished children. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word about what I am trying to do and remember to use the Indiegogo share tool!

story:
About me

My name is Edgar Vazquez and I am currently a senior majoring in both History and Anthropology at Texas Tech University. With your help I am hoping to raise funds and return to Belize in order to conduct archaeological fieldwork. In the summer of 2012 I was lucky enough to visit Belize for the first time and join the Chan Chich archaeological program hosted by Texas Tech. I will be returning in the summer of 2013 in order to gain more archaeological experience and doing what I love, while earning graduate school credit.

As a child I have always had an urging desire to become an archaeologist and hopefully one day discover something astonishing that would drastically change the archaeological world. Well, I’m a several years from doing anything along those lines. Every dream starts somewhere small. I have also made several lifelong friends from my first visit and I would love to grow as a person and future archaeologist with the ones who are returning.

During my first visit as an undergraduate student I had several scholarships and financial aid which allowed me to fund my trip without it becoming a financial burden on myself or my family. However, this time around I’m not as lucky. Being a fulltime student and working in order to not need student loans can be quite difficult and I have been extremely successful in doing this throughout my college career. However, I am faced with the difficulty of having to fund my return to the archaeological program in Belize and save up for graduate school. Thus any donation and contribute would be greatly appreciated and mean so much to me. Monetary and moral support is welcomed.

With Your Help

  1. Program Fee: $1,800 for the regular session plus $250 for the extended session which make it a total of 29 nights.
  2. Tuition:  Is roughly $1,850 for 6 hours

I have been saving money for this trip and for graduate school which has been tough. I have already purchased my round trip plane ticket which was $720. I will also try to apply for any scholarships I can qualify for.

During the archaeological program I will be surveying, mapping/profiling, and excavating various sites. The program will also consist of trips to Maya ruins at Cahal Pech and Xunantunich and various other activities like horseback riding through the jungle and bird watching.  

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if I don’t achieve my target goal the contributions I do receive will still be used from my trip. Everyone can help out just by sharing my page with friends, family, and on various social media outlets. I will be extremely grateful with any type of help! Spread the word and share! With your help I will be a step closer to achieving my dream and helping me continue my education. Contributions are also helping discover and better understand the history of the Maya Civilization which flourished in the region.

 

Thank you!

story:
• This project is for Foundation for Action Motivation and Empowerment(F.A.M.E) India which is a non-profit,non-government organisation, working towards the rehabilitation and empowerment of persons with neuro-muscular and intellectual development disabilities, such as cerebral palsy, mental retardation,autism spectrum disorders and muscular dystrophy .  

  • In the 12 years of existence, we have worked closely with thousands of differently-abled persons and their families.Based on our experience and the needs of the communities that we regularly interact with, we are developing and delivering a wide range of programs that will reduce the incidence and impact of disabilities within a larger community.

  • The Outreach Program will achieve the following objectives:

1)  To reduce the incidence of disabilities

2)  To reduce the impact of disability conditions among infants and children

3)  To work on capacity building of existing schools,hospitals and NGOs

  • Your contributions will help impact the lives of over 2000 directly and a much larger community of over 10000 indirectly.


What We Need


  • Request for support:

    Program

    Target Community

    Number of Beneficiaries

    Fixed Assets Required in USD

    Operational Expenses in USD

    Total annual cost USD

    Awareness programs and sensitization training

    Expectant mothers

    1000

      4000

      5600

     9600

    Doctors & nurses training and involvement

    100

    Local women's committee heads

    20

    Screening, identification & referral

    Children

    1000

      500

      5100

      5600

    Early intervention

    High risk infants

    200

      49000

      12000

      61000


What You Get:

In india too you can donate through the indiegogo web-site.All Indian credit cards accepted.  Donate generously.With your donations you will be changing the lives of the neglected class- the children with special needs.You will also impact the lives of the carers and family members of these children and young adults and give them confidence to cope with the challenges.

  • The funds will go a long way in starting the Outreach Program. If we do not achieve our complete annual fund target for this we will take it on a month on month basis.

The Impact

Your contribution can make a child with special needs acquire life skills for everyday living and also increase the possibility of employment through skill enhancement.The Outreach Program is aimed at multiplying the impact of handling and reducing the incidence of disabilities among children and young adults. By donating to this cause you can make a difference and contribute along with F.A.M.E team who have 12 years of experience in this area.

Be An Angel Spread The Word

Make a difference spread the word among your family,friends and office colleagues.
story_txt:
This project is for Foundation for Action Motivation and Empowerment(F.A.M.E) India which is a non-profit,non-government organisation, working towards the rehabilitation and
empowerment of persons with neuro-muscular and intellectual development
disabilities, such as cerebral palsy, mental retardation,autism
spectrum disorders and
muscular dystrophy .

 



In the 12 years of
existence, we have worked closely with thousands of differently-abled persons
and their families.Based on our experience and the needs of the communities that we
regularly interact with, we are developing and delivering a wide range of
programs that will reduce the incidence and impact of disabilities within a larger community.

The Outreach Program will achieve the following objectives:
1)  To reduce the incidence of disabilities2)  To reduce the impact of disability conditions among infants and children3)  To work on capacity building of existing schools,hospitals and NGOsYour contributions will help impact the lives of over 2000 directly and a much larger community of over 10000 indirectly.What We Need

If we do not achieve our complete annual fund target for this we will take it on a month on month basis.The ImpactYour contribution can make a child with special needs acquire life skills for everyday living and also increase the possibility of employment through skill enhancement.The Outreach Program is aimed at multiplying the impact of handling and reducing the incidence of disabilities among children and young adults. By donating to this cause you can make a difference and contribute along with F.A.M.E team who have 12 years of experience in this area.Be An Angel Spread The Word

story:
Teaching in Zimbabwe, Part 2

My Story

 

My name is James Carey. I am the Producing Artistic Director of the ATTIC Theatre Conservatory in Los Angeles, CA. A position that I have had for 25 years. Last year I was invited by Zimbabwe's National Institute of Allied Arts to come to Africa and teach workshops in Acting and Dramatic Reading, and also to judge the national Speech and Drama Festival held every year for children 7 years of age to high school students. I was the first American to ever be offered this opportunity in the entire history of the Festival. 

Because of your generous help, I was able to go. Yet, because of the amazing experience of working with NIAA and the children that they help, I returned to the USA and decided to try and find other Americans to want to go and teach theatre and speech to the children of Zimbabwe. Zimbabwe's education system operates on the British model, and Drama and Public speaking are required parts of their education. Without them, they cannot graduate high school. Because of the political upheavel of the past few years, many qualified teachers have left the country, and it is the children's education that suffers. 

This year 3 Americans will go over to help in Zimbabwe. One will have the position that I had in 2012 as festival adjudicator, (June 25 to July 10, 2013) and the other two (myself included) will be part of NIAA's Teacher Outreach Program and will go directly into classrooms all over Zimbabwe working with the teachers and the children in preparing for the 2013 Festival. (From May 13th to June20th, 2013 is the classroom portion). Teaching Drama and Speech in Africa is not about the best actor or most popular in school, it is about building self-esteem, learning goal setting, understanding team work, working beyond your comfort zone, and gaining confidence through success. In 2012, the festival drew over 16 thousand children and this year is predicted to draw even more.  

Zimbabwe's National Institute for Allied Arts was founded over a 100 years ago, and this Drama Festival and Competition has been going on continuously for 98 years through the colonial period when the country was known as Rhodesia to the present. 

 

The 3 Americans are paying their own way and the round trip cost is about $1500 per person. Each one of us will be staying in Zimbabwe from two weeks to a month. We will live in people's home and share their meals as we move around the country. 

We are trying to raise 1500 dollars to help offset some of the travel expenses of the teachers. Mostly air flight. 

Please help if you can.

Thanks

 

Website for National Institute of Allied Arts in Zimbabwe

http://alliedartszim.org/sd/sdhome.html

 

My website - www.jamesrcarey.com

The Attic Theatre Website - www.attictheatre.org 

 

The Impact

 

Without a doubt, opportunities like these will benefit both the children and the people going over. The teachers going get to give back in a way that is almost not  possible in the USA at the present time. And the children get quality instruction and the Zimbabwe teachers learn new teaching skills from theatre and speech professionals.  

 

The chance for both our cultures to learn more about each other is invaluable. The opportunity to work with so many youths doing what I love so much - theatre - is truly a blessing. I am sure that I will learn much more then they will from this experience. 

 

The ATTIC's mission is to bring communities together and to try reach out to young people and help create the new audience of the future. Finally, we view theatre as one of the greatest teaching tools around, because of it's ability to engender and create self-esteem, goal setting, team work, discipline and to break down boundaries between people.The opportunity to reach out to this group in Zimbabwe fits right into our mission. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We are trying to raise 1500 dollars to help offset some of the costs for the teachers as they travel to Zimbabwe. This could include partial air flight to Zimbabwe - $1500 coach and a 29 hours trip. It could help with expenses in Zim beyond food and room, like sundries, entertainment, and local travel. 

All the money goes to the trip and will still go toward the trip no matter what amount we raise. 

For those that give - they will receive a tax donation letter from the ATTIC. 

 

PLEASE GIVE IF YOU CAN - IT IS APPRECIATED AND EVERY DOLLAR HELPS!!!

 

ALSO PLEASE PASS THIS ON!!!

 

THANK YOU

James Carey

Executive Director, Attic Theatre Conservatory, Inc.

story:
If you missed our deadline but still want to participate dont worry, we have created an extension of this campaign here: http://igg.me/p/393048/x/1896744

 

 This is an extension of our original campaign meant for students that missed the first deadline and still want to contribute. To learn more about our previous campaign  please visit www.indiegogo.com/vfxlearning

So far we have published the first 30 out of 120 hours of training videos. We are doing this  both in  English and Spanish. We need your support in order to help us keep bringing you this material, not only with donations but also spreading the word about the campaign and the training, the material speaks for itself and the more people that watches the videos the better. 

You can also learn more about each course topics and description and watch the recordings on our website www.vfxlearning.com/videos/opensource

 We also have a Vimeo channel where you can also see the entire list of recordings: http://vimeopro.com/vfxlearning/opensource

What is the VFX Learning Open Source Project and who is behind it?

My name is Luis Pages, I'm originally from Venezuela, for the last 10 years I have been a visual effects artist in the film industry. I'm a member of the Visual Effects Society and I have worked in over 12 feature films including Avatar, Harry Potter 5, Ice Age 2, John Carter and The Lovely Bones. You can see samples of my work here www.solidanimations.com .And learn more about my efforts to change the vfx industry here : http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/lucasfilm-faces-new-pregnancy-discrimination-386863

http://vfxsoldier.wordpress.com

Learn more about the VFX Learning Open Source Project in this video recording of our most recent Open House session.

In winter of 2010 I founded VFX Learning with the sole mission of creating high end training, mentored by artists actively working in the film industry, and delivering this sessions in English and Spanish, live anywhere in the world via our online classroom.

Since our launch we have been training students from every continent and has been a phenomenal experience. But at the same time it has been painful to receive hundreds of emails from students who cannot afford the cost of the courses but that are so passionate about what we do.

This made me think about my start in this industry,how I had to work 2 jobs during the day and stay up most of the night on my dial-up internet connection hunting for any tutorial I could find, how hard it was to train and compete with artists coming from the big fancy schools, it didn't seem fair...

What I'm trying to accomplish with the VFX Learning Open Source Project is to give everyone regardless of their geographical location or financial situation a fighting chance.

I want the competition for those precious VFX film jobs to be fair. I want to give everyone the tools and knowledge they need to succeed in this business, and let creativity, imagination, talent, intelligence, hard work, desire and passion  be the determining factors in who makes it and who doesn't.

In order to achieve this I will stop operating VFX Learning under the current business model and instead we will run one last series of live mentored training with our supporters, this sessions will be recorded and released online for everyone to watch week after week until we complete the cycle.

What We Need & What You Get:

I will release as Open Source all the courses that I personally teach, this means: Maya Dynamics level 1, level 2 and Master Class, Getting Wet with RealFlow, as well as Igor Gonzalez course: Intro to Maya for Effects. All 5 courses both in English and Spanish (120 hours of video)

In order for this project to be successful I need to secure as much funding as possible to allow me to basically turn my business into a non profit open source content provider, instead of selling it to an investor who will continue under the current model who only benefits those who can afford our courses.

We managed to secure $34882 with our previous campaign and this new campaign is just an extension of the donation period.

Your contributions will also help me cover the cost of production of the 120 hours of video training (10 courses, 12 hours of class per course, in 2 languages each) , the web servers to host and stream all the video material and online student community, supporting scene files for each course, tracking of live action plates for assignments, pay our instructors for their open source content, and cover the cost of software licenses offered as perks. Plus of course IndieGoGo and PayPal's commissions (between 7 to 12% together)

I have created many different levels of donations each one with very interesting rewards. Describing each individual course will take too much space so thats why I have left the VFX Learning website intact as it is today while it stills operates as a business. This will give you an idea of what we do, how we do it, and what you and everyone else in the world will get in terms rewards in the form of training.

You can visit www.vfxlearning.com and see it for yourself. We also have a great Facebook community I'm devoted to this so I'm always available to answer any questions via email , the comments section or Skype. Ask and you shall receive :)

The Impact

If we are successful all of our contributions will give that kid in India or China, South America, Europe or Africa who sits and watches is awe how Iron Man and The Avengers save the world, or how Harry Potter defeats evil with so many cool tricks and spells, an opportunity to learn how this impressive imagery is done, and hopefully become the next generation of VFX Artists that with an open mind and warm heart will take our troubled and sometimes unfair industry into the place it deserves.


I hope that that other competitors of VFX Learning who have copied our method in the past will then follow us on this initiative. Is not easy to be the first in the water with this type of things, it changes dramatically the current paradigm and not everyone understands or agrees, but at least something is being done.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Don't worry if you cant contribute, you can help me immensely by spreading the word, tell everyone about this initiative so they can do the same. We all love movies so I'm sure someone you know will feel identified with my cause.

Also if any artists would like to contribute with course material, tutorials, etc please feel free to contact me.

If any VFX post-production houses, studios or software developers would like to participate in this project also feel free to drop me a line.

Thank you so very much for reading this long text and for your support.
