story:
Essential School Supplies Packs

The Foundation of Goodness (FoG) aims to narrow the gap between urban and rural life in Sri Lanka by tackling poverty through productive activities. With a reach of over 25,000 people across 45 villages we operate in both the North and South of Sri Lanka, aiming to lift up the poverty stricken villagers from a post-tsunami and post-war environment through a holistic model which focuses on building up the community through 30 different sectors.

Since the year 2000 the FoG has delivered over 14,000 essential school supplies packs to impoverished school children who could not afford to purchase their supply lists for a new school year. Many of the children in these rural villages go to school ill equipped to make the most of the education they receive, or drop out of school because they do not have all the items they need for their studies. Providing them with everything from shoes and a water bottle to the books and bag they need, we try to ensure that their education will not be interrupted due to a lack of essential school items.

This year we hope to deliver Essential School Supplies Packs to over 1500 students who, without our help, would be unable to complete their education to the best of their ability. Join us today, and help break the cycle of poverty these children are enmeshed in by helping make their dreams come true, and their good fortune will then help them drag a whole family out of the clutches of poverty. Everyone should have a chance to dream of a better future. Help change the fate of 1500 lives… it may just change your life!

 

What we use the money for:

USD 30 will help us assemble one pack of essential school supplies and deliver it to the school of the child beneficiary. Two types of packs will be assembled with regard to age specific requirements, please find below a complete list of items included in each pack:

 

Grade 1 to Grade 4:

1  School Uniform

1 School bag

1 Pair School Shoes and Socks

8 Exercise Books (120 pages)

6 Coloured Markers

1 Box of Coloured Pastels (Crayons) (25 pieces)

1 Drawing Book (40 pages)

1 Lunch Box

1 Water Bottle

1 Pen

1 Pencil

1 Ruler

1 Eraser

1 Pencil Box

 

Grade 5 to Grade 12 

1 School Uniform

1 School Bag

1 Pair of School Shoes and Socks

8 Exercise Books (120 pages)

1 Box of Crayons (25 pieces)

1 Box of Coloured Pencils

1 Box of Mathematical Instruments

1 CR Book

1 Pen

1 Pencil

 

Even if we do not reach our fundraising goal, all money that has been received will be used for purchasing as many school packs as can we can put together, any additional funding will help us reach even more children.

 

In a show of thanks from both us and the children, we will try and make all of our major supporters a part of this experience. Photographs of the children receiving their Essntial School Supplies Packs will be received by all contributors who donate more than USD 30 (the price of a single pack) and with higher donations we will also send you thank-you notes from the kids as well as a short video of the school packs being distributed after the event takes place. In this way, we hope to bring you closer to the joy that your donation would have brought to their young lives.

 

More about the FoG and Other Ways to Help:

The Foundation of Goodness has over 30 sectors that help uplift communitites through a variety of programs including Women’s Development, It training, Diving and Training, Pre-school, Sports, Business Skills and Psycho-social Support. To find out more about what we do, and how you can help us please visit www.unconditionalcompassion.org.

We need your help to make children’s dreams come true, please tell your friends and share this page so that we can touch many more lives.

story:
Have a business? Perhaps you would like to sponsor our efforts

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to pitch in financially, we still need your help!

Like and share on Twitter and Facebook to help spread awareness
  1. Volunteer your time
  2. Pledge your ponytail for a free haircut and gifts

 

Short Summary

I am a beauty and lifestyle writer, and I'm donating my hair to make a wig for a woman with cancer who cannot afford one while undergoing treatment.


When I learned it takes nine donations to make just one wig, and realized I'd personally thrown away four of them in my lifetime, I knew I needed to make a bigger change than merely getting my hair cut. I enlisted the help of colleagues in the celebrity beauty business, and set a goal to spread awareness about the particulars of hair donation.


I set a goal to collect 1,000 ponytails and made plans to go on a summer hair "drive" to do it. I'll be kicking off the first-annual TLC tour in Fisco, Texas on November 9, 2013, and we'll be making stops across North America through 2014.

We'll present the proceeds of our drive to Beautiful Lengths at our Growing Hope Gala and Fashion Show.

Pro Participants

Click photos to meet our pro participants on the TLC Tour.

What We Need

Our crowdfunding campaign on Indiegogo will be used to supplement  corporate sponsorships and individual donations we have already secured through our personal outreach efforts.

It will enable us to launch our charity and provide the funds for not just the summer tour expenses, but all the equipment we'll need to achieve our objectives: To conduct year-long educational and governmental outreach, and summer tour events annually.

 

Objectives

Conduct an annual hair drive to collect at least 1,000 ponytail donations and recruit new professional and press participants to the cause.

Organize public wellness events and wellness workshops for influential members of new and mainstream media outlets to maximize the TLC message.

Create a hub for the public to discover hair donation programs and free wig outlets globally.

Acquire commitment of each cosmetology board in the United States to incorporate simple hair donation education into accredited programs for hairstylist licensure.

Recruit and train salons worldwide to take hair donations correctly, and provide each with a supply kit for accepting and returning donations to be made into wigs.

Establish free wig programs worldwide where they do not currently exist, starting with Brazil.

The Impact

With the collection goal we've set for our summer drive alone, more than 100 women with cancer will receive free wigs. Our ongoing outreach efforts will ensure that no stylist ever discards hair that could be used to create a free wig, and that all salons will be equipped with kits that enable them to easily send donations for processing.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Justin Durham, and for the last six years I have worked toward my dream of becoming a Doctor. During that time I have gotten married, had two children, joined and served in the US Army and worked upwards of four jobs at a time to maintain financial stability while I attended school. After endless hours of studying and striving to achieve my goal I have finally been accepted to medical school and have my dream within reach. 

Unfortunately, and despite all my efforts to save money, I am unable to pay even the expenses required to make it to medical school. I will be moving my family half way across the world, but I cannot even afford the cost transportation of myself, let alone my family and our belongings.

This campaign is to raise the money I need to get me and my family to medical school, and if you help you will not only be helping a dream come true but you will be affording an opportunity for the world to have a potentially great physician.

What We Need

The medical school that I have selected to attend is in the Caribbean on an island called St. Vincent. The name of the school is Trinity School of Medicine. I expect that I will need around $5000 for traveling and moving expenses.

Expected expenses:

Airfare: $700 per ticket x 4 = $2800  

Passports: $170 per person x 4 = $680

Shipping: $800

Lodging: $100

Food: $200

Transition Money (On Arrival): $220

 TOTAL: $4800 

Leaving Around $200 for unexpected expenses.

Any and all money will go towards the transition to our new home and toward success at school. If there is more than expected left over then all proceeds will go toward paying for school itself. 

The Impact

I have always struggled to ask for help, and I have considered it a learning experience to struggle and toil at accomplishing my goals. My work ethic has always been outstanding and I have dedicated so much time and energy to making it to medical school that I cannot imagine being held up by a few thousand dollars that it will take to just make it to medical school. 

Having to ask for help has humbled me and shown me that I must rely on others just as others will one day rely on me. Gaining money from the hospitality and generosity of complete strangers will only motivate me that much more to the very best that I can. I will not fail when I know that there are so many cheering me on. Thank you.

story:
Short Summary

Swings for Dreams is a grassroots nonprofit dedicated to  improving the lives of children in third-world and developing countries through the design and construction of safe, sustainable, and culturally sensitive play spaces. Through the construction of safe outdoor play spaces in some of the most under-served regions of the world, we hope to increase school attendance worldwide and to combat the tragic loss of childhood, which goes hand in hand with living in these politically volatile areas.

The funds raised from this campaign will enable Swings for Dreams to fund the construction costs to build a safe outdoor play space for a primary school located in Nieu-Bethesda, South Africa. Play has been scientifically proven to have countless physical and psychological benefits. And, it's necessary for healthy early childhood development. Not only will these funds be bringing a playground to Nieu-Bethesda, but this money will also create hope in this South African community--hope for the future and for a better tomorrow.

UPDATE: Thank you to everyone who has donated to our campaign thus far. We are forever grateful for your generosity & support. You are truly making a difference in the lives of the children in Nieu-Bethesda. Our team wanted to send a quick update to anyone that has donated or is thinking about donating...Even if we do not make our $30,000 goal, we are going to South Africa to build a playground. Ultimately, we will update our initial design to one that is more feasible financially. So, continue to spread the word and donate. We'll be heading to South Africa in August, rain or shine!

What We Need & What You Get

In order to fully fund all of the construction materials for our project this summer, we need to raise $30,000. Each and every donation will go toward making the dreams of our team members and the children living in Nieu-Bethesda a reality. Every cent counts! Please help us bring hope to this community so that kids can be kids, despite the hardships they face. 

Not to worry-- If we don’t reach our entire goal, all of the funds donated to our campaign will still be going toward funding the playground this summer.  We are strong believers in the power of play and are determined to make this playground a reality. Please help us help the kids!

If our mission speaks to you and you’d like to play a critical part to bring a play structure to the kids of Nieu-Bethesda, Swings for Dreams would love to give you a little something in return to show our appreciation. Check out our perks for more detail.

The Impact

Today, there are many children that do not have the luxury of growing up with a happy and carefree childhood. Instead, they are forced into premature adulthood as a result of extreme poverty, social and political instability, malnutrition, violence, racism, and the loss of loved ones–often times being one or more of their parents. This is the harsh reality for children living all over the world and this is especially true for the children living in South Africa. 

UNICEF defines an orphan as “a child under the age of 18 years whose mother, father, or both biological parents have died.” There are roughly 3.85 million orphans living in South Africa today. Without parents to help guide and nurture these children, many are left homeless, hopeless, and hungry. They often quit attending school and end up getting into trouble. For children living in the most under-served regions of the world, education is the only tool they have to break the vicious cycle of poverty. Discontinuation of school can have devastating effects on the rest of their lives.

In the words of the great leader, Nelson Mandela: “Education is the most powerful weapon which you can use to change the world.” The team at Swings for Dreams could not agree with this statement more, but the issue in a lot of these areas is not the lack of schools. The issue is more about student retention—getting kids to keep attending school once they have started. For kids given the opportunity to have an education, finishing their studies should be a top priority, but often times it is not. Understandably, students who have lost parents or are left to take care of themselves and their families, quickly lose their motivation to attend class. But, our team has found a simple solution to get kids motivated to keep attending school: play.

Kids are more inclined to want to go to school if there is an incentive—and we believe outdoor play keeps kids motivated. Not only does play serve as a positive reinforcement to keep children in school so that they can eventually break free from poverty, but it has countless other physical and developmental benefits. Kids who play outside are happier, healthier, and stronger. They are leaner, have stronger immune systems, get more Vitamin D, have lower stress levels, and have more active imaginations. American Clinical Psychologist, Kay Redfield Jamison, writes that “Children need the freedom and time to play. Play is not a luxury. Play is a necessity.” The fact that safe, free, outdoor play is not available to all children worldwide is a crime against humanity. Kids need the freedom to be kids, and play can do just that.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren’t able to make a monetary donation, but you are interested in joining Swings for Dreams in fulfilling its mission, please spread the word about our organization and what we do. And, feel free to forward the link to our Indiegogo campaign to your friends and family!

Swing on!

You are truly making a difference in the lives of the children in Nieu-Bethesda. Our team wanted to send a quick update to anyone that has donated or is thinking about donating...Even if we do not make our $30,000 goal, we are going to South Africa to build a playground. Ultimately, we will update our initial design to one that is more feasible financially. So, continue to spread the word and donate. We'll be heading to South Africa in August, rain or shine!What We Need & What You Get

In order to fully fund all of the
construction materials for our project this summer, we need to raise $30,000. Each and every donation will go toward making the dreams
of our team members and the children living in Nieu-Bethesda a
reality. Every cent counts! Please help us bring hope to this community so
that kids can be kids, despite the hardships they face. 
Not to worry-- If we don’t
reach our entire goal, all of the funds donated to our campaign will still be
going toward funding the playground this summer.  We are strong
believers in the power of play and are determined to make this playground a
reality. Please help us help the kids! 
If our mission speaks to you and
you’d like to play a critical part to bring a play structure to the kids of
Nieu-Bethesda, Swings for Dreams would love to give you a little something in
return to show our appreciation. Check out our perks for more detail. 

The Impact
Today, there are many children that
do not have the luxury of growing up with a happy and carefree childhood.
Instead, they are forced into premature adulthood as a result of extreme
poverty, social and political instability, malnutrition, violence, racism, and
the loss of loved ones–often times being one or more of their parents. This is
the harsh reality for children living all over the world and this is especially
true for the children living in South
Africa.  
UNICEF defines an orphan as “a child
under the age of 18 years whose mother, father, or both biological parents have
died.” There are roughly 3.85 million orphans living in South Africa today.
Without parents to help guide and nurture these children, many are left
homeless, hopeless, and hungry. They often quit attending school and end up
getting into trouble. For children living in the most under-served regions of
the world, education is the only tool they have to break the vicious cycle of
poverty. Discontinuation of school can have devastating effects on the rest of
their lives. 
In the words of the great leader,
Nelson Mandela: “Education is the most powerful weapon which you can use to
change the world.” The team at Swings for Dreams could not agree with this
statement more, but the issue in a lot of these areas is not the lack of
schools. The issue is more about student retention—getting kids to keep
attending school once they have started. For kids given the opportunity to
have an education, finishing their studies should be a top priority, but often
times it is not. Understandably, students who have lost parents or are left to
take care of themselves and their families, quickly lose their motivation to
attend class. But, our team has found a simple solution to get kids motivated
to keep attending school: play.
Kids are more inclined to want to go
to school if there is an incentive—and we believe outdoor play keeps
kids motivated. Not only does play serve as a positive reinforcement to keep
children in school so that they can eventually break free from poverty, but it
has countless other physical and developmental benefits. Kids who play
outside are happier, healthier, and stronger. They are leaner, have
stronger immune systems, get more Vitamin D, have lower stress levels, and have
more active imaginations. American Clinical Psychologist, Kay Redfield
Jamison, writes that “Children need the freedom and time to play. Play is
not a luxury. Play is a necessity.” The fact that safe, free, outdoor play
is not available to all children worldwide is a crime against humanity. Kids
need the freedom to be kids, and play can do just that.
Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren’t able to make a monetary
donation, but you are interested in joining Swings for Dreams in fulfilling its
mission, please spread the word about our organization and what we do. And, feel
free to forward the link to our Indiegogo campaign to your friends and family!Swing on!

story:
A Mission to Learn!

I have been training dogs for 5 years. I love learning new skills and have the opportunity to attend a hands-on seminar at Service Dogs, Inc. in Dripping Springs, TX, this summer. The cost is $1,500 plus travel expenses, and I cannot go unless I receive funding.

Details

This is a 5 day seminar where I will learn how to train...
  • Hearing Dogs - Alert owner to sounds such as: 1) doorbell, 2) telephone, 3) kitchen timer, or 4) a person trying to get their attention
  • Service Dogs - Assist owner (usually wheelchair-bound) by: 1) opening doors, 2) picking up objects and handing them to the owner, 3) assisting the owner in putting his/her legs in place on the wheelchair, 4) turning on lights, etc.
I will be working hands-on with dogs currently in the training program at Service Dogs, Inc...
  • Teaching commands and alerts to the dogs currently in training
  • Learning how to select dogs for the program on-site at a local shelter
  • Working the dogs in the field (at stores, restaurants, etc.)
Go here to read more about the seminar:
http://www.servicedogs.org/workshop-content

Please consider donating so that I can help others.

If funding goals are not reached, you will receive a refund.

story:
Migrant Farmworker Children's Education Project: Local Focus, Statewide Impact

Statement of the Case. After working with farmworker families in migrant labor camps in California for the past eleven years, Human Agenda and the Center for Farmworker Families seek to change a state regulation to allow migrant farmworker children in Santa Clara County and California to stay at one school year-round, and succeed.

Under existing state regulations migrant families in 24 federally subsidized California migrant laborcamps are forced to move at least 50 miles away when the growing season is over, forcing the disruption of their children’s education. These children are required to attend a different school from November to May, the heart of the school year. The result is the dramatic undermining of the main reason the migrant laborers came to the United States in the first place: to improve the lives of their children through quality education.

We need your donations to jump-start our campaign.

We will introduce the bill this February, conduct research and garner the support of other organizations from March till May, and sign the bill into law by Governor Brown in September. To carry this out, we expect to need upwards of $50,000. Your donations on Indiegogo will kick-start our fundraising!

The Impact

This bill will directly impact children's ability to graduate High-School, and help end the cycle of poverty.

Currently only 10% of migrant farmworker children graduate from high school; compared to 50% among farmworker children that do not migrate. The impact this regulation would have would directly contribute to a child's ability to graduate! 


Help us spread the word!

You can help by donating and by sharing this campaign with your friends and family on facebook and social media. Together we can help level the playing field for farmworker children.

story:
Short Summary

The Edmonton Poetry Festival Verse Project is dedicated to working with students and teachers to help establish a lifelong interest in poetry and the literary arts. Our program helps students learn to love words and increases literacy. We send poets into to classrooms to present poetry workshops and to help youth explore their own unique voice and how it can be used in poetry. You can read more about the program at http://edmontonpoetryfestival.com/poets-in-the-schools/ 

What We Need & What You Get

We need $5000.00 to support this program for one year. This allows us to pay our poets and to administer the program. This funding will enable to us to go into 40 schools this school year, allowing us to reach approximately 1200 students. Every contributor will be recognized on through our website and social media. Tax receipts are available for contributors. 

The Impact

The program, was established in 2006 and until now was available only during the poetry festival week. Each festival week we host roughly 15 poetry workshops, bringing poetry to nearly 500 students per year. That’s approximately 3500 students who have been engaged in poetry since we began. 

It is time to expand and offer this program to those students who have been unable to access it during festival week. Teachers have asked us to provide workshops at other times of the year to fit with their curriculum needs. 

By bringing poetry into classrooms, students meet face to face with writers who can convey the pleasures of creating and sharing poems. Teachers learn tips and techniques they can use with their classes in the future. We build connections. We build bridges in literary communities that we hope will continue long after the poet leaves the building. 

Words From a Student

“Being a young writer comes with a lot of uncertainty and excessive experimenting. By being given the opportunity to meet writers from an assortment of different subject areas and genres, a youth who is either dabbling or neck-high in words is then able to really solidify the art-form to themselves. At least, that's what it was like for me. By being exposed to all the different types of poetry and general mediums of writing, my world was blown. Specifically meeting and getting to work with poets who are published and are in their adulthood, but still writing, just gave me an extra confidence boost in my own potential. It is one thing reading about poets and their general careers and lives, but it's another thing meeting one and actually getting to work with one. I am overjoyed that I was given this opportunity throughout my schooling and hope that many others get the same opportunity.” --- Harleen Cheema


Other Ways You Can Help

Please consider passing on a link to this campaign to your friends and family. Or send them to our website at www.edmontonpoetryfestival.com to become a member. All membership funds go towards helping us showcase poetry in Edmonton.

story:
Why Nepal? Why Nima?

We, Hanna, Sarah, and Tom, are three Seattleites who have volunteered at the Nepal Peace Home in Sarlahi, Nepal--a reconciliation orphanage for children who fell victim to Nepal's violent Maoist insurgency from 1996-2006. This ten-year-long civil war killed the families, mostly fathers, of children throughout the nation, making resources and the chance for a bright future nearly impossible. Nima is one of those children. He is the oldest child at Nepal Peace Home and the first to graduate from high school. This means that he will move away from the children's center soon. If we don't act now, he will have nowhere to go. 

Nima completed high school this month--far more education than either of his parents received. When his family was no longer able to care for him, he was sent to a children's home and given the chance to continue his primary and secondary education. Thus far, he and many of the students at the center have been supported by generous sponsors from Unity Church of Fairfax in Virginia. He has already overcome immense obstacles to reach where he is today. He is an incredibly dedicated student and a kind, loving boy, who truly exemplifies peace and stewardship for his 40 "brothers and sisters" at the children's center. Please help us show Nima that his hard work has paid off and provide him with his right to an education.


What Nima Needs

  • $1,020 will provide Nima with school, accommodations, food, and books for one year. This breaks down to $85 a month; less than $3 a day.
  • Nima will begin college within the next two months, as long as funds are provided.
  • If we don't reach our entire goal, all funds will still go directly to Nima's school and living costs.
  • If we raise funds beyond our initial goal, all remaining proceeds will go directly to our upcoming college project for the rest of the children at Nepal Peace Home. Stay tuned for more information, or ask us about it!
  • Because communicating with Nepal is so difficult and Nima has few to no resources, we have taken matters into our own hands. Hanna Morrison, a volunteer who lived in Nepal at the Peace Home for six months, is going back in July 2014 to ensure that all the children are doing well, but namely, that Nima has an advocate for his education. We know that the most effective and trustworthy way to guarantee Nima's needs are met is to manage his college costs ourselves.

From Nima

Despite his stutter and a propensity to face the ground when he speaks, Nima exudes a rare breed of leadership and quiet strength that is hard to find among children who have endured such violence and loss. We think Nima deserves to go to college. We can tell you lots of wonderful things about him. But why does he want to go to college? Here's what Nima has to say for himself:

Q: How much education did your parents receive?

A: My mom and dad are not educated due to lack of money and family support. My father and mother were working in some factories. the relations between my father and mother were not husband and wife. My dad was the husband of my mom's sister, but my father and mother used to work in the same garment factory and at that time my mother wasn't married but she had contact with my father and became pregnant. Our society didn't accept that condition, i.e. having child before the marriage at the age of 15. My mom had some mental problem and also could not speak. She left me due to the fear of society and she immediately married another man. At that time I was alone and no one took care of me. At last my grandmother knew these things and she took me and raised me up from childhood and sent me to school and took care of me and paid me many facilities and she gave me love and affection and enjoyment during that time. I stayed there until class 4 and after that she sent me to the hostel. I was 11 years old. And from that time my life has continued in hostel. I have not worried about those matters when I came to the hostel. When I get holiday I go to my grandmother to help her.

Q: Why do you want to go to college?

A: I want to go to college for my higher studies and to make my future bright and make my experience good compared to others and to get the higher education through all the systems. Nepalese people are not educated and hence our country is backward compared to others. Nepalese people have to bear many problems and I want to be educated and eradicate the evils or the problems which directly or indirectly harm the country. I want to achieve my personal future goals and make a better life. When people are busy in household works they cannot concentrate on their studies. I will graduate my higher study properly and make my future bright and I think I want to develop the nations like Nepal.

Q: What do you want to study in college and why?

A: I want to study commerce because it helps to run my life properly and it helps to make future bright. As we know it is an interesting subject because it teaches about trade. Trade is the act of buying and selling the goods from one country to another. There is no trade balance in Nepal. If Nepal exports the raw materials to other nations we can earn foreign currency, which helps to maintain our life. Most of the people sell the raw materials expensively. I will decrease its price and by studying commerce I will help solve these problems and make trade balance.

I want to do something for my nations. I will make a good relationship between my neighboring countries and other countries. And I will also build mutual understanding among the people from one place to another and stop the corruption by making people aware of how our country is backwards in all these systems. It helps make the relationship among countries and helps maintain the financial work by conducting different types of programs and it helps to make the strong policy. I will make the border line strong among the natives and also give more facilities to other people and also give them more salaries. Commerce will help me to perform the different works related to any field. It makes the national income strong . It will sustain my life and support my future continuously.

Q: What are your biggest educational and career goals?

A: I will pass my degree in commerce and after that if my sponsors support me then I will study. My aim is to become the accountant which helps me to gain the knowledge and provide me a lot of information and through this I will obtain many experiences and skills. I have also decided to take the many methods through these systems and I would become the honest accountant who is liked by everyone. In Nepal, many accountants are not honest and they take money. I will run my life in a better way and make different ideas and methods to show others they can be good. My aim will help me to raise my status and raise my family status in all types of activities because now I am low caste. I will make plans and policies so the government may be aware there are problems. and eradicate the social problems which are seen in this country. I want to make economic policies. This education will help me to start positive habits and start on a good path. And from that I will develop my life.

Q: How will this scholarship help you?

A: It will support my future and make me able to face any kind of problem that occurs. It will give me more facilities and a lot of pleasure. it will help to make my studies better and my life will move forward. It may also help me get the chance to study in the higher college and from it I can learn many things and then support my own life properly. There will be less difficulty in my life this way. And my parents may be happy to listen and they will look at me and it will develop my skills towards the study and I can get a lot of facilities and there will be no obstacles in my life and I can easily run my life with the help of others. I can support my family and my nation which has already helped me. It will make me happy and lead me to do any kind of work I want. I can show my brothers and sisters they can also study in higher education.


Other Ways You Can Help

  • Help us spread the word by sharing our campaign with family and friends!
  • Stay tuned for more information and a real life, full-blown website for Nepal Peace Home coming soon. Here, you'll be able to learn about all the kids at the Nepal Peace Home and how you can help them, just like Nima, as they embark on their collegiate journeys. Help Nima be their first example.

story:
Over the course of this year the Diploma and Advance Diploma students have been fundraising to hold a showcase of our work over the last 2 - 3 years. 

Rez Up will showcase the work of 60+ animation, game or interactive digital media students of the East Perth Central Tafe campus. Students have been raising money in order to hold this event, but we need some extra help.
Our on campus fundraising has been going well, but we need an extra push in order to add the finishing touches to our industry night and public open day events.
  

What We Need 

While we have been going well with our own on campus fundraising efforts we are seeking an extra $500 to cover the final costs of promotions and set up for our industry night. 

Even if we are unable to reach our full $500 goal all the money we do raise will still be put towards the following:

  • Promotional printing and distribution.
  • Catering.
  • Security.
  • Equipment and furniture hire.
  • Various other costs for the evening.

Risks & Challenges

As always there is a chance we will not be able to reach our goal, with whatever money we do manage to raise it will all be going towards our expo. As always every little bit counts and we are very appreciative of the support we have and continue to receive. 


Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can donate money. If that's the case we would appreciate if you could share and raise awareness for both our cause and exhibition. 



__________________

We have chosen to raise our money in USD because indiegogo will not accept credit card donations in AUD. Sorry for any inconvenience this may cause. 

__________________

Our on campus fundraising has been going well, but we need an extra push in order to add the finishing touches to our industry night and public open day events.

While we have been going well with our own on campus fundraising efforts we are seeking an extra $500 to cover the final costs of promotions and set up for our industry night. 
Even if we are unable to reach our full $500 goal all the money we do raise will still be put towards the following:

Promotional printing and distribution.
Catering.
Security.
Equipment and furniture hire.
Various other costs for the evening.
   Risks & Challenges
  As always there is a chance we will not be able to reach our goal, with whatever money we do manage to raise it will all be going towards our expo. As always every little bit counts and we are very appreciative of the support we have and continue to receive. 

  Other Ways You Can Help We understand that not everyone can donate money. If that's the case we would appreciate if you could share and raise awareness for both our cause and exhibition. 


__________________
We have chosen to raise our money in USD because indiegogo will not accept credit card donations in AUD. Sorry for any inconvenience this may cause. __________________

story:
Hello again.


I am turning my attention towards 8ring in the next few weeks, and I'm ready to put down my workshop into a video. After teaching at festivals for the past several years, I've had to redevelop a lot of my approach to finger positioning and some small changes to my technique eventually unlocked a whole new world of spinning potential.

So I'm announcing a new workshop : 8 Rings in Ukiah.

A one hour tutorial focusing on core techniques for the fingers, concepts for isolation and working with double-sets of rings. 


Pre-registration is open now at $15, and $25 gets you beta access to see the content as it is being uploaded during the remainder of September. The timeline for this project is : Film and edit in the next 16 days, and release at the start of October.

Registration for the workshop is what makes the workshop happen

Regardless of whether a workshop is happening in your own town, or online, the same situation applies. If an instructor cannot get enough interested students to join the workshop, the workshop doesn't happen.

  • Sign-up for the workshop! Let me know you want this. $15 for a basic registration with a whole world of new techniques for you to explore in return.
  • Tell friends of yours who might also be interested in the workshop. Right now is the time when I need the community support the most, so help me engage other groups and communities to spread the word about this project!
  • 8Rings aren't your thing, but want to see the project happen? Give me a high five ($5) and I will include you in a special thank you video of new techniques that I will release for subscribers and supporters only.

8-Rings are the new hottness

It's happening already. 8ring videos are getting millions of views on youtube. The public has loudly exclaimed "OMG this stuff trips us out!". What we need next is a generation of 8ring spinners armed with the fundamentals of good technique. This is what I am proposing to help create, and I'm asking for your help to get there.

story:
As the current crisis in South Sudan continues to unfold, now is the time to begin thinking about the long-term means for preventing a relapse into violent conflict. When the terrible violence against civilians recedes, there will be significant need for reconciliation and building of resilience within the communities of South Sudan, and very limited capacity for addressing those needs. Accordingly, standing up this center will be one element of a long-term commitment to preventing future outbreaks of inter-ethnic violence in the world’s newest nation.  By conducting research on the causes of violence in South Sudan, incubating an advocacy community for prevention and conducting training for officials both inside and outside of government, the center will support and help sustain key constituencies working to ensure this round of violence is the last for years to come.

The Center will be directed by Nixon Andu Amos. Nixon brings an unparalleled combination of experience and academic training to leading CPEC. Currently serving as an Atlas Corps Fellow through a U.S. State Department supported program and the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, Nixon is a scholar-practitioner with the resume and network to effectively lead this organization. He holds a BA in Political Science from the University of Stockholm and an MA in Holocaust and Genocide Studies from Uppsala University, Sweden. In his professional career, Nixon served as an advocate working for the inclusion of civil society voices in the CPA negotiations, as a cross-cultural trainer to the Swedish military prior to deployment in UNMISS, and as a lecturer on South Sudan’s history and culture.

Funding:

The funding requested here will support a pilot study to conduct outreach with potential institutions to house the center, conduct research and interviews with civil society leaders and expand the director’s contacts with other organizations working to end the current conflict.

Problem Assessment:

The fighting currently tearing South Sudan apart is at its core a power struggle between elite factions of our society. This struggle has spun into a full-fledged ethnic conflict, in part, due to the limited capacity and weak processes within the government, and a lack of restraining factors across South Sudanese society. Weak governance and a lack of established process for the effective functioning of the state leaves too much room for corruption and placing the goals of the individual over the good of the people. As South Sudan begins the long road to recovery and the building of a stable, effective and representative government, it will be critical that a conflict prevention lens of analysis has a central role in shaping that planning process. In particular, if a new transitional government is agreed upon to end the current crisis, the successful transition to longer-term institutions will depend on the ability to apply conflict sensitive approaches to those arrangements. Avoiding a relapse of conflict and protecting all of South Sudan’s populations is critical to creating the stability necessary to establishing a “new normal” in the country without war and without the killing of civilians.

Problem address: (strategic what/strategic who)

South Sudan faces multiple challenges in the aftermath of over 20 years of conflict, including: weak governance, limited education, limited infrastructure and lack of cohesive national identity. These challenges will take at least a generation to overcome; however, the foundations of that recovery must be laid today. To achieve that goal, the Center for the Prevention of Ethnic Conflict (CPEC) proposes to work in three key areas:

1.)  Research: There exists a robust body of research that continues to grow examining the best methods for preventing ethnic conflict and mass atrocities. The Center will serve the dual role of applying that body of knowledge to the situation in South Sudan and making that research policy relevant, and conducting original research on the divisions and avenues for reconciliation within the currently fractured country. In this capacity, CPEC will serve as a pivotal bridge that will apply the best research on the challenges facing South Sudan and translate those ideas into actionable policy.

2.)  Advocacy: a critical component to advancing any proposal on the future of South Sudan will require a broad-based constituency supporting change. Accordingly, CPEC will work to incubate an advocacy community focusing on the issue of conflict and atrocity prevention. As this community grows, it will have ability to advance the prevention agenda with other civil society actors as well as the government and international organizations.

3.)  Training: Building the capacity of organizations doing related work in this field is an important step in building capacity within South Sudan. CPEC will initially undertake training geared toward key practitioners and opinion-makers to facilitate understanding of risk factors, warning signs, and triggering and escalating factors, and connecting those factors to tools for preventative action. Incorporating these frameworks into the activities and analysis of South Sudan’s civil society leaders and policy professions will help enable this community to continue maturing as a capable force for action in our society.

story:
My dear family and friends:

As most of you know, I have loved to perform ever since I was a young child. All the years of dedication, classes, theatre troupes and singing have finally paid off... in an amazing opportunity to attend AMDA. The training will be intensive and extensive. All the instructors and professors are working professionals and I will be immersed in the arts! However, the tuition is high, and although I've been awarded a scholarship of $4,000 per year, there are many more dollars I must raise.  We have some wonderful incentives for your donations, and remember, any amount helps.  Thank you so much, in advance.  : )

Here's a bit about me... I did not choose the path of an artist, the path chose me. It was something I was born with, something that defined me at a young age. My mom (Gypsy) discovered this about me when I was only nineteen months old. At the time, my absolute favorite movie was Bambi and my mom had a VHS that she had running, practically continuously, in my bedroom. As the story goes... when I was in my parent's room playing with my toys, Bambi could be heard on the baby monitor in their room. Bambi happens to have almost no dialogue, but instead the story is told through its images and a musical score to communicate what is happening in the scenes throughout the movie. I was told that while sitting there, I began to recite the actions of the scene by just hearing the soundtrack through the baby monitor. Both my parents couldn't believe their eyes as they rushed into my bedroom, ecstatic to find that my explanations were spot on. They were amazed that I could identify the corresponding actions happening in the movie by hearing the soundtrack. Mom told me that at that moment, she knew I had the gene - the calling for art. It started with my love for music at such a young age and blossomed through the years to come with my discovery of the theatre. 

When I was five years old, my love of acting and the theatre began. I got the opportunity to perform in my first musical, "Joseph and the Amazing Technicolour Dreamcoat," at Crossroads summer camp. We worked six hours a day for six weeks to prepare for the production. Every summer thereafter for the next five years, there was a new play, new auditions and a new character through which I had the opportunity to express myself. I also participated in musical productions with Miss Amanda's Stage Kids theatre troupe throughout the school years after that first experience at summer camp prompting my love of performing in the theatre. One of my most cherished moments was being honored with the role of Elphaba in "Wicked." I cannot truly express the way it feels to perform. Putting it into words just doesn’t quite capture the extent to which I feel connected to life and joy when I am performing. Art is everything to me: it is the way I cope, the way I learn, the way I express my feelings and myself. Without art, the world wouldn't be the same place and I wouldn't be the same person.        

Your contributions will go directly to tuition and housing.  The schedule is rigorous and requires that I be in classes from 8:00am until 5:00pm, with rehearsals in the evenings so living on campus is necessary.  Contributors will receive my immense gratitude and promise of dedication and hard work.  This is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity for me, and a dream come true!  Also, I will always strive to use my success for positive changes and contributions in the world.  I give you my word.

Love,
Isabella

P.S. Please click on Gallery above to see photos of all perks.

story:
In short

We need your help to feed and keep warm the helpless ones in the refugee camps in Lebanon... 10 dollars can feed a family of 5 a day... can you afford it!

Help us to help them... see how they live

Syrian Refugees in Camps

Syrian kids are suffering!!! Help us helping them


What We Need & What You Get

What we need is you contribution... donate the price of a morning coffee and a donut...

What will you get... nothing tangible, an appreciation and a prayer! That we can promise.... 

The Impact

You know what difference you can make... A better world, at least for a day.

Other Ways You Can Help

Every dollar count and will defiantly help, so help us by spreading the word... We are sure that your friends and family will be able to pitch in....

story:
Name: Jessica Grady
Age: 22
Profession: Registered nurse/student midwife.

As part of my midwifery studies, I was given the opportunity of an international placement. The typical placement is Laos.... but like usual, I wanted to be different.
My first choice was Thailand. However, I was severely disheartened by the lack of autonomy midwives have in Thailand.... and this lead me to Ghana, in West Africa.
I have secured my placement at Magro Maternity Clinic which is in the center of Kasoa, Ghana.

Unfortunately, volunteering isn't free. In fact, I have a huge amount to pay. From placement costs, accommodation, insurance, food, flights, visas, passport.... the list goes on. 

Magro Maternity Clinic is small and lacks resources. As a qualified nurse and a midwife in training, I will be able to offer my skills and help the learning of the employees of the clinic. Any extra money raised will go toward the clinic.

story:
The Shockoe Sessions Recording Camp is a two week intensive workshop for High School Juniors, Seniors and College Freshman in music production.  The camp is held at In Your Ear recording studios located in Downtown Richmond, VA.  The purpose is to bring creative, musically driven students into the real world of modern music production from both aesthetic and technical perspectives. The camp promotes interaction between recording artists, producers, engineers and representatives from top pro-audio manufacturers.  For the past two years, The Shockoe Sessions have hosted top bands and top students from central Virginia resulting in tremendous experiences for everyone involved.  So what happens if you have the talent and desire but lack the financial resources to attend? How can we offer this experience to those who can’t afford the tuition?  The answer is sponsorship.  For just $500, we can admit a deserving student to the July sessions.  The discounted $500 tuition covers all expenses for the two weeks, six hours daily, Monday through Friday and includes a healthy lunch.  Students will experience music production from the inside by working with professional engineers and producers.  They’ll learn how hard working professional artists bring what they do to the outside world. They’ll study the proper use of microphones, analog processing gear, popular audio software and learn how these are used in professional recording.  They’ll also meet and connect with others who share their love of music and the craft of music production.  Students will be selected based on enthusiasm, talent and financial need. The Greater Richmond YMCA, the CHAT program, and JAMinc, all top charitable organizations who work with Richmond’s youth population, will identify the best candidates.  Why should you help? 

  1. Arts funding has been radically cut from Central Virginia’s Schools, private educational opportunities are now essential to learning these skills.
  2. Only students with adequate financial resources are likely to attend the Shockoe Sessions Camp due to the $850 tuition
  3. Richmond is quickly becoming a hub for entertainment related businesses including major television series, blockbuster movies and album production, yet our local workforce lacks the necessary skills to work in these industries.  Without skilled labor, the entertainment business will seek other cities offering better developed talent.  We need to start at the High School level and we need to do it now.

story:
Short Summary


We met in 2010 on an online dating website.  I knew he was the one in February 2011 when my brother Raymond passed away suddenly for an illness. My brother had no children and never been married. He was my best friend.  Doug and I were only dating for a year when this happened. He was there for me and my family during this emotional time. Doug has continued to support me and my family till this day.

  After that I knew he was the one and we got married in 2012. It was the best decision we ever made. Just before our wedding, I experienced my pain in my side that would come and go. We didn’t have insurance at the time. It was discovered that I have uterine fibroids and a lot of them. In 2013, my period stopped and the doctor told me that my hormone levels were low and to see a specialist. That specialist couldn’t help me and sent me to the Fertility Center. After more tests were done, if you know me then you know I don’t like needles, we found out that both of my Fallopian tubes were blocked. Due to the blockage the egg and sperm can’t meet. We also was told that I had a low Ovarian Reserve count. All women are born with a certain amount of  eggs. In order for us to have a chance to have a baby we would have to do in vitro fertilization. IVF involves combining eggs and sperm outside the body in a laboratory. Once an embryo or embryos form, they are then placed in the uterus. Also we have to have Intracytoplasmic Sperm Injection (ICSI) allows the injection of a single sperm into an egg.  These procedures are very expensive and extremely time sensitive.

What We Need & What You Get

Luckily we have insurance through Doug’s job but there are some things not covered like the deposit for IVF and any of the pretesting, medications, office visits and copays. So we are asking for contributions our dreams come true. Like in life, there are no guarantees that IVF will be successful. But that is a chance that Doug and I want to take.

We are asking for $5,500. We know this is a large amount to ask people to contribute. This amount includes 1,200 IVF deposit that is not covered by insurance. ICSI procedure is $1,477 and is not covered by insurance. Lastly, depending on what kind testing , medications and what part of  IVF that is not covered by insurance  .

If we don’t reach our goal of $5,500, we will use the money towards to the IVF and ICSI procedures.  Please donate what you can. All amounts are appreciated.

Perks:

We have perks for each designated amount. From a warm Fuzzy Feeling, to a hand written note from Doug and I to Facebook and Twitter Shouts, to a video Thank You , a family pictures and be one of the few people to get to know the sex of the baby.



    The Impact

    When Doug and I found out about my infertility, I was devastated and ashamed. I thought it was my fault. That I waited to too long. I felt how many people with this disease felt, broken. But I have a great support system offline and online. My husband said this to me. “I still love you and you are not broken.” That was big to me. My very close friends who are like my sisters have had our back from the start. My parents were on board with whatever decision we made.

    I searched online for information and support groups. There were a lot of information out there. When I searched for African American infertility, it was few resources and articles about the subject. I  was on Facebook and a friend had an African American support group on her page. I clicked it and started to cry. I wasn’t alone. There were people who looked like me and had similar issues with infertility. They spoke about their trials, tribulations, and the lack of information regarding women of color.

    1 out of 8 couples had been diagnosed with infertility. African American couples are less likely to go to the doctor due to lack of insurance and  negative cultural stereotypes. Some couples feel ashamed and the stigma surrounding it. So they suffer in silence.

    Again we wanted to let you know that there are no guarantees that IVF will work. We want a chance to build our family.

       


      Other Ways You Can Help

      If you can't contribute that is okay. Please   spread the word about our campaign on Facebook and Twitter. Also we really would love comments and prayers as well.
story_txt:
Short Summary 

We
met in 2010 on an online dating website.  I
knew he was the one in  February 2011 when my brother Raymond passed away suddenly
for an illness. My brother had no children and never been married. He was my best friend.  Doug and I were only dating 
for a year when this happened. He was there for me and my family during this emotional time. Doug
has continued to support me and my family till this day.
  After that I knew he
was the one and we got married in 2012. It was the best decision we ever made. Just
before our wedding, I experienced my pain in my side that would come and go. We
didn’t have insurance at the time. It was discovered that I have uterine fibroids
and a lot of them. In 2013, my period stopped and the doctor told me that my
hormone levels were low and to see a specialist. That specialist couldn’t help
me and sent me to the Fertility Center. After more tests were done, if you know
me then you know I don’t like needles, we found out that both of my Fallopian
tubes were blocked. Due to the blockage the egg and sperm can’t meet. We also
was told that I had a low Ovarian Reserve count. All women are born with a
certain amount of  eggs. In order for us to have a chance to have a baby we would have
to do in vitro
 fertilization. IVF involves combining eggs and sperm outside the
body in a laboratory. Once an embryo or embryos form, they are then placed in
the uterus. Also we have to have Intracytoplasmic Sperm
Injection (ICSI) allows
the injection of a single sperm into an egg. 
These procedures are very expensive and extremely time sensitive. 

   What We Need & What You Get 

Luckily we have insurance through Doug’s job but there are
some things not covered like the deposit for IVF and any of the pretesting,
medications, office visits and copays. So we are asking for contributions our
dreams come true. Like in life, there are no guarantees that IVF will be
successful. But that is a chance that Doug and I want to take.
We are asking for $5,500. We know this is a large amount to
ask people to contribute. This amount
includes 1,200 IVF deposit that is not covered by insurance. ICSI procedure is $1,477 and is not covered
by insurance. Lastly, depending on what kind testing , medications and what part of  IVF that is not covered by insurance  .

If we don’t reach our goal of $5,500, we will use the money
towards to the IVF and ICSI procedures. 
Please donate what you can. All amounts are appreciated. 


Perks:
We have perks for each designated amount. From a warm Fuzzy
Feeling, to a hand written note from Doug and I to Facebook and Twitter Shouts,
to a video Thank You , a family pictures and be one of the few people to get to
know the sex of the baby.




  The Impact 
When Doug and I found out about my infertility, I was devastated
and ashamed. I thought it was my fault. That I waited to too long. I felt how
many people with this disease felt, broken. But I have a great support system
offline and online. My husband said this to me. “I still love you and you are
not broken.” That was big to me. My very close friends who are like my sisters
have had our back from the start. My parents were on board with whatever
decision we made. 
I searched online for information and support groups. There
were a lot of information out there. When I searched for African American infertility,
it was few resources and articles about the subject. I  was on Facebook and a friend had an African American support group on her page. I clicked it and started to cry. I wasn’t
alone. There were people who looked like me and had similar issues with
infertility. They spoke about their trials, tribulations, and the lack of
information regarding women of color. 
1 out of 8 couples had been diagnosed with infertility.
African American couples are less likely to go to the doctor due to
lack of insurance and  negative cultural stereotypes. Some couples feel ashamed and the stigma surrounding it. So
they suffer in silence. 
Again we wanted to let you know that there are no guarantees
that IVF will work. We want a chance to build our family.
  
  Other Ways You Can Help If you can't contribute that is okay. Please   spread the word about our campaign on Facebook and Twitter. Also we really would love comments and prayers as well.

story:
Hello, there...

I'm an Indian girl who has grown up in a family that encouraged its children to learn and appreciate music and dance. As a child, I was introduced to classical ballet and western piano. Since then, I have completed close to 15 years of practice and tutoring of both ballet and piano.

Though I love playing the piano, it is ballet that gave me more opportunities. I was a keen student. We got ample opportunities in our ballet school to showcase our choreography skills, even when we quite young. At the age of 15, I was invited by my ballet instructor to join her as an additional teacher for the growing number of students our school had begun to admit. Since then, I have taught over 60 students ranging from ages 4 years to 50 years. I had also been invited to teach at several other places, and I chose to teach at my music school.

It was this experience and the joy I associated with managing to educate as well as be loved by each of my students that made me determined to pursue a career within dance education. I had begun to build a dream that involved creating a unique and extensively planned institute for performing arts in India that would spread the love I had formed for dance education, with collaborations from other renowned and upcoming exponents of performing arts.

I did my undergraduate studies in Economics from one of the best colleges in India. Ballet took a back seat during those years, for I could not simultaneously spend enough quality time on both academics and dancing. I had planned to restart my ballet practice right after complete my B.A. focus on getting college education in the same. It is around this time that I suffered an injury which affected my spine, and delayed my return to practice.

I applied for a place in Trinity Laban Conservatoire in London, UK, because Indian institutions provide college level education in Indian performing arts only. This is one reason why I feel that there is a great need for institutes like the one I have planned to start so that students do not have to travel abroad for getting a good education in disciplines like ballet.

For this to be realized, however, I still need my academic base to be built by getting educated at a top college in the world, myself. I got admission to M.Sc. Dance Science at Trinity Laban. I chose the programme because I identify with it completely. I convinced the admissions committee with my experience of being injured as a dancer and teacher, and how I want to educate other dancers by focusing on the physiology and psychology of the dancer.

The next step, now, is to finance this goal. My family is unable to bear the burden. Even servicing a loan is near impossible. I had secured this admission last year, and had to defer it by one year because my family was unable to afford the expenses. This year, we have still not been able to raise the requisite funds.

That is when I thought of crowd-funding as an option and decided to reach out to all of you.

I hope you can help...

My entire course, which is a one-year programme, getting there and stay at Trinity Laban Convservatoire of Music and Dance will cost me roughly about GBP 32,000. The course fee itself is GBP 16,100. Of this, Trinity Laban has offered me a fee reduction of GBP 4,000.

The costs for getting to Trinity will be roughly around GBP 2,000, inclusive of visa, airfare and insurance. Since I will be staying at Trinity Laban's residence halls, the costs that have been calculated for me come to about GBP 16000.

Any and every bit of contribution will help me get one step, or two, closer to realizing this dream. I urge each and everyone of you to help in any way you can. Even a GBP 1 contribution will help me immensely.

Some of the perks on contributing a certain amount include:

  • A personalized and loud THANK YOU on my Facebook page, on contributing GBP 50
  • A personalized handwritten photo postcard from when I get to Trinity Laban, on contributing GBP 100
  • An Indian silk kurta/kurti/stole/dupatta, AND a personalized handwritten photo postcard, on contributing GBP 250
  • One Indian tussar hand-block printed silk saree OR salwar-kurta-dupatta set, AND a personalized handwritten photo postcard, on contributing GBP 500
  • A set of three sketches by well-known Indian artist Vivan Sundaram, AND a personalized handwritten photo postcard, on contributing GBP 1000
  • A water colour and mixed media work by another well-known Indian artist Rummana Hussain, AND a personalized handwritten photo postcard, on contributing GBP 2500
  • A three-night stay for a family of four at any of Club Mahindra's resorts in India, subject to availability, on a stay-only basis (Food, taxes, other expenses, and travel to the destination will have to be paid for separately), AND a personalized handwritten photo postcard, on contributing GBP 10,000
You can also help by:

  • Sharing and re-sharing this campaign page with any and every one you know.
  • Sending me your best wishes and prayers to my email: vinita.abraham@outlook.com
  • Contributing, and urging anyone you can tell to contribute, even the smallest amount possible - every penny counts here.

CONTRIBUTION OPTIONS:

For ease of contribution, we have enabled PayPal for this campaign.

As you contribute, you will be provided with an invoice that has my brother's name on it, as the account is in his name.

You do not need a PayPal account to contribute. As per the guidelines given:

"To make a contribution using PayPal, the contributor can either sign in to a PayPal account or elect to "Pay as a Guest." If someone chooses "Pay as a Guest", they can use a credit card without having a Paypal account. For instructions on how to Pay as a Guest on PayPal, please visit:  How to Contribute via PayPal without a PayPal Account."

Thank you!

As per the guidelines given:"To make a contribution using PayPal, the contributor can either

story:
We're GROWING where the GROWN folks are. 

My name is Angie Harvey and I've decided that GROWN folks everywhere should be given the opportunity to GROW up.  Through H.O.P.E. (Healing Our People Emotionally) Ministries I plan to host the 2014 GROWING Folks Day Retreat Tour where I will visit 12 cities in 12 months starting in April 2014.  

I will go to whatever city I'm able to get a low or no cost venue that will comfortably accommodate at least 50 people.  There will be no cost to attend the retreat and anyone who wants to GROW can participate.  I will act as the primary facilitator and will cover topics such as personal GROWTH, relationships, emotional healing, letting go and purposeful living. 

What We Need & What You Get

The funds will be used for venue space, supplies, marketing, promotions, travel, accommodations and other expenses for the facilitator, and vendors as needed. 

Never fear, you'll receive something in addition to my forever gratitude for contributing.  All contributors (any donation is appreciated) will be acknowledged on website, social media and any printed materials if so desired.  Any donation at or above $50 will receive a free DVD or CD, $100 or more will receive a free DVD or CD AND a T-Shirt , $500 or more you'll have the honor of being identified as a co-sponsor of a particular city tour, and $700 or more will have the option of picking a host city and having their name being identified as the co-sponsor.

The Impact

In this day and age we have a wealth of knowledge at our finger times but there are limited resources that provide ways to adequately use the information.  I'm a firm believer that you can't change the color of your world unless you apply the paint (the knowledge).  This retreat will allow anyone who has the desire to participate to learn and GROW emotionally, mentally and spiritually.  

***Other Ways You Can Help

The campaign is also in need of any knowledge or contacts you have about low or no cost venues, marketing and promotions personnel, and you talking about it and me behind my back by forwarding this link to your family, friends and anyone who might want to contribute to this GROWTH campaign.  

Thank you in advance for your support.  Here we GROW again!!
