story:
The Request:

Please help spread the word. If enough people hear about this and can contribute even just $20, this dream will be realized. Please read my story below. If you believe that I am a worthy person to invest your money in and if you believe I am able to make good on these goals, please help us reach our dreams by contributing toward allowing me to finish this degree. 

I need to pay for my final Undergraduate degree classes

I just have this term and next to complete:

  • This term costs $2327.29 and covers one programming class, and two art history classes. I am in finals next week.
  • Next term will cost around the same amount for one statistics class and one additional class of any kind that will give me the 8 credits total needed to continue to reside in student housing. 
  • If I cannot pay it all off before the end of December then we must move but any monies contributed will go to the school bill.

I will continue on to Graduate school and help the HUB grow

By making these two terms happen for me you allow me to get out of default, finish my undergraduate degree and enroll in Graduate school where I will get my Masters in Management. I aim to use the Masters program to help the Hospice Unique Boutique grow into the organization that it has the potential to become. By helping me you help a very worthy organization that helps numerous people at the end of their lives find solace.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word :)

 

How I started

Let me begin by saying that I have never given up and do not intend to now. My life has been full of a tremendous number of challenges but bit by bit I have found a way to overcome each of them as I set my sights on it. I am just a few classes from my Bachelors of Science degree in Art, Digital Media with a Minor in Art History-- and I need financial help to overcome a current hurdle and finish this.

1969 I started out in a remote cabin five miles outside of 29 Palms, California. My parents were poor and uneducated but they managed. When I was 18 months old I contracted meningitis. It destroyed the left temporal region of my brain, put me into a coma and paralyzed the entire right side of my body. I remained at Los Angeles' Children's Hospital until I was 3 years old. When I left I still had nearly constant grand mal seizures but had recovered much of my mobility. The state wanted my parents to sign me over to institutionalized care but they refused. By the time I was five the seizures had pretty much disappeared. Even so, the doctors at the time felt that I would never be capable of attending school nor living a normalized life. My parents refused to believe that and fought to allow me to attend public school in regular classes.

1974 School was not easy for me and a disruptive home life did not help, so by the time I was in fourth grade I still could neither read a book nor a clock. Many of the teachers just passed me without trying to teach me because it was easier than the alternative.

1979 That is, until I entered fifth grade and was blessed to have Charles Gimby as my teacher. He refused to accept that I was a lost cause. Within those nine months I went from illiterate to the top of my class and received the school-wide award for the most improved student. That year I also began volunteering for the Morongo Eagles Special Olympics program. I helped to encourage the competitors to achieve their best and saw that I had a lot of experience to offer. That began my lifelong commitment to volunteering in my communities. From fifth grade on I did very well in school with the exception of algebra. The damage to my brain as an infant made it impossible for me to be able to retain abstract math.

1980 This year my siblings and I went into private school. It was a small school but the curriculum allowed you to work as fast or as slow as you wanted. I blazed through course after course and loved it! That year I also completed my first marathon, raising more money myself than all of the other runners combined. I made fund-raising a regular part of my volunteerism.

1985 Every Winter and Summer break I visited my dad in Arizona. He was now living near Sedona, Arizona. I began volunteering throughout these breaks at Kachina Pointe Retirement hospital. Helping the elderly find joy toward the end of life gave me tremendous satisfaction and gave me many wonderful memories with some truly amazing people.

1987 My guidance counselor in high school said that there was no way I would ever be able to attend college because of my algebra disability and did not try to give me paths to achieve it. Neither of my parents had attended college and my step-father was not able to direct me. Even though I was, at that time, the town queen and was soon to spend a year in Indonesia as an exchange student, people still saw me as not worthy of a college degree.

1988 When I returned from Indonesia my home life was in shambles. We moved to a town just outside of Palm Springs. I was working in a children's store near Palm Springs for about eight months but learned of a high-paying opening with the US Department of Agriculture for the summer. I took the summer position as a USDA Ag Inspector which afforded me the funds to attend one semester of college. My step-Great-Grandfather died suddenly  that Fall followed by my Step-Father a few days after Christmas. My mother was unable to cope with the loss and went to stay at a recovery facility in Palm Springs.

1989 I began seven classes at Copper Mountain Community College that January while my mother was being treated. I split care of my little sister with my step-grandparents. When my mother returned a few months later I let her know that I was intending to move out so that I could focus on college. Apparently she wasn't in a healthy mental state yet and her response to my intention of leaving left me with no alternative but to flee to my grandparents home that night. In order to save me they helped me to move abruptly to Portland, Oregon. It meant that I wouldn't be able to take finals that semester, so my classes that were otherwise straight A's were negatively affected.

1990 I enrolled in Portland Community College a few months later when I had gotten somewhat settled in Portland. There I met the fellow student that would keep me from completely losing all ground and who would be there through everything that happened next.

1991 Toward the end of January I came down very sick. Within a week I was having difficulty walking. Seizures started again after being gone for nearly 15 years. I had to withdraw from school while the doctors tried to determine what was wrong. The fellow student and I moved in together so that he could help take care of me. My arms were very weak, I was endlessly fatigued and needed two canes to walk any distance at all. The doctors suspected Multiple Sclerosis and began treating me for that. I was 21. It would be a year before I would rebound and be back to normal. 

As soon as I could walk reasonably well again I sought out work so that I could get back on my feet. I went through Vocational Rehabilitation and was placed as a Market Researcher. (I rapidly grew in that company and was in charge of focus groups and international research when I left five years later.)

1992 The student that had been there through all of difficulties now became my husband and a year later we had our first child. Over the next ten years I climbed the corporate ladder despite numerous repeated attacks on my body by what they thought was MS, including a six month period of quadriplegia while pregnant with my second child.

2001 When I reached 31 I was an Account Manager for a large telecommunications company and personally managed twenty Fortune 200 clients. I wanted to go further with the company but needed to have my degree in order to do so. I had saved a lot of stock and we decided to move to Ashland, Oregon to attend Southern Oregon University and get our degrees. (My husband had to drop out of school all those years before to help take care of me). We moved down here in August of 2001. In September, 9/11 happened, and the stock market crashed. My telecommunications company didn't recover so the stocks that had been worth well over $130 each were now worth .13 cents each. 

I was working as a buyer at a local gift and household goods store, Paddington Station and my husband was working as a line cook at a The Wild Goose Cafe, so we figured we would manage. And we did. We did very well in college and it looked like our lives were finally pointing in the right direction for the next two years.

2003 But in February 2003 I was struck by another severe attack, the very worst yet. This time it also caused my liver to start to fail, affected my heart and the quadriplegia would last well over one year. The doctors now changed the diagnosis from MS to a rare form of Muscular Dystrophy called Hypokalemic Periodic Paralysis probable Andersen-Tawil variant. My husband continued to go to school, work and raise the children while I was trapped in my body and unable to help. 

2005 I did finally recover and we began to get our lives back in order once again when I had a stroke. It greatly affected my language center which, I would later learn, effectively wiped out the languages I had previously known, such as Indonesian, Malaysian, French, and German. For the next year I sounded somewhat drunk but my mind was seemingly normal aside from the foreign languages. In college I was intending to get my Bachelors of Arts degree but when I tried to take French class. Not only was the French no longer there in my brain, I could barely retain any new French language. Foreign language is a requirement for a Bachelor's of Art degree. Instead of giving up I changed my degree to a Bachelors of Science and began taking all of the needed science courses to apply to that degree change.

2008 School went well until early March 2008 when I had another attack of quadriplegia, this time just from my torso down. I was able to continue with school after taking a few weeks off to adjust to navigating campus in an electric wheelchair and training my dog to carry my books and sit quietly for long stretches in a classroom setting. I continued straight on until nearly my last classes. I only needed one quantitative and one qualitative course to graduate but if I added two Art History classes I would also get my minor in Art History. 

2009 That Summer I was anticipating being finished with my undergraduate degree very soon. Through it all I had maintained a high GPA and felt like the hard part was behind me. I was very close with my father and he was quite vocal with anyone who would listen about how proud he was of me. I spoke with him regularly but I had noticed he was beginning to be behaving strangely and his posts on Facebook were increasingly strange. Around the same age my father now was, his father had committed suicide. So I asked him, point blank, if he was intending to kill himself. He swore up and down that he wasn't. He unfriended me on Facebook that week but a few weeks later he re-friended me. He again swore that he wasn't planning on ending his life yet on September 9th he did just that with a bullet to his head. He apparently believed that 09/09/09 was an auspicious date and that he would be reunited with a long lost love that day in heaven.

I withdrew from school that Fall to go to Arizona and take care of his things and his funeral (there wasn't anyone else in his life to do it) and planned on returning in Winter to school. Unfortunately that December I had another severe attack, much worse than most of the ones before. No treatment was helping and it looked like there wasn't going to be any way to overcome it this time around. I also developed a melanoma on my leg that took two surgeries to fully remove and a year later they would tell me that I had uterine cancer, the same cancer my mother was dying from. Fortunately, the uterine cancer was a misdiagnosis. 

2011 By Fall I was chronically ill and figured that I had a year or so left in me. In December I had developed a serious sinus infection and went to the clinic to get antibiotics. The usual doctors weren't there so a specialist who volunteered at the clinic once a month saw me instead. As he was looking over my chart he remarked that I was one of the luckiest people in the world. When I asked him why on earth he would even think that, he said that he was pretty sure I had been misdiagnosed all this time and, if so, that my life was about to change tremendously. The disorder he was suspecting happened to be his specialty, a specialty that a very small number of doctors in the whole country would have recognized.

2012 January A round of tests were run and it was verified that I did not have MS or Muscular Dystrophy but had actually been born with a genetic inability to absorb B-vitamins called Homocystenuria and it is fully treatable. These days every baby that is born in the US is tested for it at birth when they draw blood from the heel prick. They are testing for homocystenuria as well as phenylketonuria. After decades of wrong turns and false hopes I didn't believe a word of it. He then showed me the vitamin levels in my tests. Every single one was severely deficient--not just all of the B-Vitamins but all of them--calcium, magnesium, zinc, vitamin D, etc. We began treatment.

March By March I felt like I was a teenager again! It was BEAUTIFUL!! And hard to believe that it would be like that forever but I immediately took advantage of it and began to take steps toward getting my life back.

At that same time we were living in student housing while my husband was finishing his Masters in Management degree. We found out that the University needed to tear down our house and move us into a different one. We moved while I looked for a job. I still was challenged by bone and joint problems stemming from the dengue fever I contracted in Indonesia and the decades of damage done by having vitamin and mineral deficiencies. Although they do cause pain, the overall quality of my life is extraordinarily better than it has been since I was a kid.

May I found a position at an amazing local non-profit called the Hospice Unique Boutique. It is a high quality resale boutique that supports end-of-life care programs and last wishes in the Rogue Valley. In their first year they were able to gift $5000 to those programs, in their second year they gifted $10,000. This year they gifted $30,000!!! I accepted the position as the Assistant Manager. It is the most wonderful shop to experience and the most rewarding place I have ever had the pleasure to support. If you are from this area you have to check it out (www.hospiceuniqueboutique.org), or friend them on Facebook and you will see what I mean.

Around the time that we moved is when I contacted the Department of Education and Direct Loans to get back to school. They told me that they would put my loans into forbearance, because we were too poor to pay any loans at the time, and then when I returned to school again in Fall it would automatically roll over into deferment while I was a student. 

June During the next few months my eldest daughter graduated from high school, my youngest daughter graduated from middle school, we became short-term foster parents for another girl and we moved my eldest daughter to Portland to attend Portland State University as a double major in Physics and Theatre.

October I returned to school and felt overjoyed! Being is school is tremendously rewarding for me and all of the possibilities of having my degree are very close at hand. I love to learn, I love the academic environment and I love the daily challenges. I am grateful to be there every single day.

November I am now going into finals with one Max/MSP/Jitter Programming class, and two 400 level Art History classes. But this week, November 26th, 2012, I found out that my student loans had not actually been sent to forbearance but instead were in default because they say they sent me paperwork in March that I didn't return to them. I don't doubt that they sent the paperwork but I have not seen it. This would have been during the time we were moving, so it likely got lost in the shuffle. All this time that I thought that my loans were in forbearance and rolling into deferment they weren't and now it is too late to fix it.

December In order to correct it I have made arrangement to make 10 months of payments which will get the loans out of the default status. But right now I have to pay for this term, which is $2327.29 and the upcoming next term which will be around the same. If I can't do that by December 28th then I am likely to lose my student house and have to move, which I don't have the funds for either. And I won't be able to finish my degree nor go in to the Master's program where they have already told me they would love to have me.

My husband has recently started his own business after months of unsuccessful job hunting. He does web design and marketing for restaurants and has recently obtained his first client but because he has just started this business he has only made a small amount of money and my work only earns enough to cover our basic costs. There is no way that we can come up with $2327 this month nor next without your help.
story_txt:
The Request:
Please help spread the word. If enough people hear about this and can contribute even just $20, this dream will be realized. Please read my story below. If you believe that I am a worthy person to invest your money in and if you believe I am able to make good on these goals, please help us reach our dreams by contributing toward allowing me to finish this degree. 
I need to pay for my final Undergraduate degree classes
I just have this term and next to complete:


This term costs $2327.29 and covers one programming class, and two art history classes. I am in finals next week.
Next term will cost around the same amount for one statistics class and one additional class of any kind that will give me the 8 credits total needed to continue to reside in student housing. 
If I cannot pay it all off before the end of December then we must move but any monies contributed will go to the school bill.
I will continue on to Graduate school and help the HUB grow
By making these two terms happen for me you allow me to get out of default, finish my undergraduate degree and enroll in Graduate school where I will get my Masters in Management. I aim to use the Masters program to help the Hospice Unique Boutique grow into the organization that it has the potential to become. By helping me you help a very worthy organization that helps numerous people at the end of their lives find solace.
Other Ways You Can Help
Please spread the word :)
 
How I started
Let me begin by saying that I have never given up and do not intend to now. My life has been full of a tremendous number of challenges but bit by bit I have found a way to overcome each of them as I set my sights on it. I am just a few classes from my Bachelors of Science degree in Art, Digital Media with a Minor in Art History-- and I need financial help to overcome a current hurdle and finish this.
1969 I started out in a remote cabin five miles outside of 29 Palms, California. My parents were poor and uneducated but they managed. When I was 18 months old I contracted meningitis. It destroyed the left temporal region of my brain, put me into a coma and paralyzed the entire right side of my body. I remained at Los Angeles' Children's Hospital until I was 3 years old. When I left I still had nearly constant grand mal seizures but had recovered much of my mobility. The state wanted my parents to sign me over to institutionalized care but they refused. By the time I was five the seizures had pretty much disappeared. Even so, the doctors at the time felt that I would never be capable of attending school nor living a normalized life. My parents refused to believe that and fought to allow me to attend public school in regular classes.
1974 School was not easy for me and a disruptive home life did not help, so by the time I was in fourth grade I still could neither read a book nor a clock. Many of the teachers just passed me without trying to teach me because it was easier than the alternative.
1979 That is, until I entered fifth grade and was blessed to have Charles Gimby as my teacher. He refused to accept that I was a lost cause. Within those nine months I went from illiterate to the top of my class and received the school-wide award for the most improved student. That year I also began volunteering for the Morongo Eagles Special Olympics program. I helped to encourage the competitors to achieve their best and saw that I had a lot of experience to offer. That began my lifelong commitment to volunteering in my communities. From fifth grade on I did very well in school with the exception of algebra. The damage to my brain as an infant made it impossible for me to be able to retain abstract math.
1980 This year my siblings and I went into private school. It was a small school but the curriculum allowed you to work as fast or as slow as you wanted. I blazed through course after course and loved it! That year I also completed my first marathon, raising more money myself than all of the other runners combined. I made fund-raising a regular part of my volunteerism.
1985 Every Winter and Summer break I visited my dad in Arizona. He was now living near Sedona, Arizona. I began volunteering throughout these breaks at Kachina Pointe Retirement hospital. Helping the elderly find joy toward the end of life gave me tremendous satisfaction and gave me many wonderful memories with some truly amazing people.
1987 My guidance counselor in high school said that there was no way I would ever be able to attend college because of my algebra disability and did not try to give me paths to achieve it. Neither of my parents had attended college and my step-father was not able to direct me. Even though I was, at that time, the town queen and was soon to spend a year in Indonesia as an exchange student, people still saw me as not worthy of a college degree.
1988 When I returned from Indonesia my home life was in shambles. We moved to a town just outside of Palm Springs. I was working in a children's store near Palm Springs for about eight months but learned of a high-paying opening with the US Department of Agriculture for the summer. I took the summer position as a USDA Ag Inspector which afforded me the funds to attend one semester of college. My step-Great-Grandfather died suddenly  that Fall followed by my Step-Father a few days after Christmas. My mother was unable to cope with the loss and went to stay at a recovery facility in Palm Springs.
1989 I began seven classes at Copper Mountain Community College that January while my mother was being treated. I split care of my little sister with my step-grandparents. When my mother returned a few months later I let her know that I was intending to move out so that I could focus on college. Apparently she wasn't in a healthy mental state yet and her response to my intention of leaving left me with no alternative but to flee to my grandparents home that night. In order to save me they helped me to move abruptly to Portland, Oregon. It meant that I wouldn't be able to take finals that semester, so my classes that were otherwise straight A's were negatively affected.
1990 I enrolled in Portland Community College a few months later when I had gotten somewhat settled in Portland. There I met the fellow student that would keep me from completely losing all ground and who would be there through everything that happened next.
1991 Toward the end of January I came down very sick. Within a week I was having difficulty walking. Seizures started again after being gone for nearly 15 years. I had to withdraw from school while the doctors tried to determine what was wrong. The fellow student and I moved in together so that he could help take care of me. My arms were very weak, I was endlessly fatigued and needed two canes to walk any distance at all. The doctors suspected Multiple Sclerosis and began treating me for that. I was 21. It would be a year before I would rebound and be back to normal. 
As soon as I could walk reasonably well again I sought out work so that I could get back on my feet. I went through Vocational Rehabilitation and was placed as a Market Researcher. (I rapidly grew in that company and was in charge of focus groups and international research when I left five years later.)
1992 The student that had been there through all of difficulties now became my husband and a year later we had our first child. Over the next ten years I climbed the corporate ladder despite numerous repeated attacks on my body by what they thought was MS, including a six month period of quadriplegia while pregnant with my second child.
2001 When I reached 31 I was an Account Manager for a large telecommunications company and personally managed twenty Fortune 200 clients. I wanted to go further with the company but needed to have my degree in order to do so. I had saved a lot of stock and we decided to move to Ashland, Oregon to attend Southern Oregon University and get our degrees. (My husband had to drop out of school all those years before to help take care of me). We moved down here in August of 2001. In September, 9/11 happened, and the stock market crashed. My telecommunications company didn't recover so the stocks that had been worth well over $130 each were now worth .13 cents each. 
I was working as a buyer at a local gift and household goods store, Paddington Station and my husband was working as a line cook at a The Wild Goose Cafe, so we figured we would manage. And we did. We did very well in college and it looked like our lives were finally pointing in the right direction for the next two years.
2003 But in February 2003 I was struck by another severe attack, the very worst yet. This time it also caused my liver to start to fail, affected my heart and the quadriplegia would last well over one year. The doctors now changed the diagnosis from MS to a rare form of Muscular Dystrophy called Hypokalemic Periodic Paralysis probable Andersen-Tawil variant. My husband continued to go to school, work and raise the children while I was trapped in my body and unable to help. 
2005 I did finally recover and we began to get our lives back in order once again when I had a stroke. It greatly affected my language center which, I would later learn, effectively wiped out the languages I had previously known, such as Indonesian, Malaysian, French, and German. For the next year I sounded somewhat drunk but my mind was seemingly normal aside from the foreign languages. In college I was intending to get my Bachelors of Arts degree but when I tried to take French class. Not only was the French no longer there in my brain, I could barely retain any new French language. Foreign language is a requirement for a Bachelor's of Art degree. Instead of giving up I changed my degree to a Bachelors of Science and began taking all of the needed science courses to apply to that degree change.
2008 School went well until early March 2008 when I had another attack of quadriplegia, this time just from my torso down. I was able to continue with school after taking a few weeks off to adjust to navigating campus in an electric wheelchair and training my dog to carry my books and sit quietly for long stretches in a classroom setting. I continued straight on until nearly my last classes. I only needed one quantitative and one qualitative course to graduate but if I added two Art History classes I would also get my minor in Art History. 
2009 That Summer I was anticipating being finished with my undergraduate degree very soon. Through it all I had maintained a high GPA and felt like the hard part was behind me. I was very close with my father and he was quite vocal with anyone who would listen about how proud he was of me. I spoke with him regularly but I had noticed he was beginning to be behaving strangely and his posts on Facebook were increasingly strange. Around the same age my father now was, his father had committed suicide. So I asked him, point blank, if he was intending to kill himself. He swore up and down that he wasn't. He unfriended me on Facebook that week but a few weeks later he re-friended me. He again swore that he wasn't planning on ending his life yet on September 9th he did just that with a bullet to his head. He apparently believed that 09/09/09 was an auspicious date and that he would be reunited with a long lost love that day in heaven.
I withdrew from school that Fall to go to Arizona and take care of his things and his funeral (there wasn't anyone else in his life to do it) and planned on returning in Winter to school. Unfortunately that December I had another severe attack, much worse than most of the ones before. No treatment was helping and it looked like there wasn't going to be any way to overcome it this time around. I also developed a melanoma on my leg that took two surgeries to fully remove and a year later they would tell me that I had uterine cancer, the same cancer my mother was dying from. Fortunately, the uterine cancer was a misdiagnosis. 
2011 By Fall I was chronically ill and figured that I had a year or so left in me. In December I had developed a serious sinus infection and went to the clinic to get antibiotics. The usual doctors weren't there so a specialist who volunteered at the clinic once a month saw me instead. As he was looking over my chart he remarked that I was one of the luckiest people in the world. When I asked him why on earth he would even think that, he said that he was pretty sure I had been misdiagnosed all this time and, if so, that my life was about to change tremendously. The disorder he was suspecting happened to be his specialty, a specialty that a very small number of doctors in the whole country would have recognized.
2012 January A round of tests were run and it was verified that I did not have MS or Muscular Dystrophy but had actually been born with a genetic inability to absorb B-vitamins called Homocystenuria and it is fully treatable. These days every baby that is born in the US is tested for it at birth when they draw blood from the heel prick. They are testing for homocystenuria as well as phenylketonuria. After decades of wrong turns and false hopes I didn't believe a word of it. He then showed me the vitamin levels in my tests. Every single one was severely deficient--not just all of the B-Vitamins but all of them--calcium, magnesium, zinc, vitamin D, etc. We began treatment.
March By March I felt like I was a teenager again! It was BEAUTIFUL!! And hard to believe that it would be like that forever but I immediately took advantage of it and began to take steps toward getting my life back.
At that same time we were living in student housing while my husband was finishing his Masters in Management degree. We found out that the University needed to tear down our house and move us into a different one. We moved while I looked for a job. I still was challenged by bone and joint problems stemming from the dengue fever I contracted in Indonesia and the decades of damage done by having vitamin and mineral deficiencies. Although they do cause pain, the overall quality of my life is extraordinarily better than it has been since I was a kid.
May I found a position at an amazing local non-profit called the Hospice Unique Boutique. It is a high quality resale boutique that supports end-of-life care programs and last wishes in the Rogue Valley. In their first year they were able to gift $5000 to those programs, in their second year they gifted $10,000. This year they gifted $30,000!!! I accepted the position as the Assistant Manager. It is the most wonderful shop to experience and the most rewarding place I have ever had the pleasure to support. If you are from this area you have to check it out (www.hospiceuniqueboutique.org), or friend them on Facebook and you will see what I mean.
Around the time that we moved is when I contacted the Department of Education and Direct Loans to get back to school. They told me that they would put my loans into forbearance, because we were too poor to pay any loans at the time, and then when I returned to school again in Fall it would automatically roll over into deferment while I was a student. 
June During the next few months my eldest daughter graduated from high school, my youngest daughter graduated from middle school, we became short-term foster parents for another girl and we moved my eldest daughter to Portland to attend Portland State University as a double major in Physics and Theatre.
October I returned to school and felt overjoyed! Being is school is tremendously rewarding for me and all of the possibilities of having my degree are very close at hand. I love to learn, I love the academic environment and I love the daily challenges. I am grateful to be there every single day.
November I am now going into finals with one Max/MSP/Jitter Programming class, and two 400 level Art History classes. But this week, November 26th, 2012, I found out that my student loans had not actually been sent to forbearance but instead were in default because they say they sent me paperwork in March that I didn't return to them. I don't doubt that they sent the paperwork but I have not seen it. This would have been during the time we were moving, so it likely got lost in the shuffle. All this time that I thought that my loans were in forbearance and rolling into deferment they weren't and now it is too late to fix it.
December In order to correct it I have made arrangement to make 10 months of payments which will get the loans out of the default status. But right now I have to pay for this term, which is $2327.29 and the upcoming next term which will be around the same. If I can't do that by December 28th then I am likely to lose my student house and have to move, which I don't have the funds for either. And I won't be able to finish my degree nor go in to the Master's program where they have already told me they would love to have me.
My husband has recently started his own business after months of unsuccessful job hunting. He does web design and marketing for restaurants and has recently obtained his first client but because he has just started this business he has only made a small amount of money and my work only earns enough to cover our basic costs. There is no way that we can come up with $2327 this month nor next without your help.

story:
Summary

Hi Everyone!
I'm Marguerite and I was born in Haiti but raised in Brooklyn,New York. My family moved to America because my father has Polycystic Kidney Disease and he could not get adequate treatment in Haiti.

In January 2010 I graduated from CUNY Brooklyn College with a BS in Business Administration, but by October 2009, having taken an intro to acting class and seeing my brother perform in a play at Amherst College I got the acting bug. Right after I got that degree, (going to school full time and working part time) I started to read books about acting and researching where I should start. I auditioned and got the opportunity to be part of some projects but it was only reading William Esper's The Actors Art and Craft that I became serious. I joined the William Esper Studio and decided to dedicate my life to it because I realized that acting had chosen me. And right when I decided to do this, my father, who had been on a waiting list for eighteen years, received a kidney. I felt the stars were aligning.

I am proud to say that as of June, I am a graduate of the Esper Studio(listed as one of the Top 25 drama schools in the world) class of 2013. And even prouder to announce that I have been accepted into the Masters of Arts Theatre Lab program at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Arts in London(listed in the Top 10 of the Top 25 drama schools). One out of hundreds who applied.

But it is expensive!!

This fundraiser is setup to help me with the cost of the program and housing. I fully intend on getting a job to support myself.

The door is open, I just need to walk in there. This is where I need your help.

Besides being a hard and dedicated worker, this opportunity is important to me because I truly believe that the Arts can positively impact the world,creating a sense of peace. Being part of RADA's MA Theatre Lab program is how I can better learn to spread that peace.

I act to share stories and to make connections in a world where a lot of us feel lost and alone. A great work of Art can show us not only the idea but give us the feeling of connection. I think the feeling is what we need most of all.

What I Need & What You Get

Okay here we go! Specifics for the money, where your money is going and why you can trust me:

I'm asking for $40,000 which includes the course payment and housing accommodation for 51 weeks. This includes the fee deductions for Indiegogo and payment processing fee. This will leave me with approximately $1,600 which can cover my student visa fee and a flight to London.

The total amount for the course is £14,000 = $21,548.80

Student housing, which will be at PURE Hammersmith is £13,014.85 = $20,032.69

  • this includes rent for 51 weeks: laundry, Internet service and utilities. (This will make the follow up emails a lot easier to send , as well as research for any school projects.
  • the location for the housing is 35 mins away from RADA and a safe area.

Making the total £27,014.85 = $41,367.83

I have put in all the savings that I have towards this
This amounts to $6,000 =£3,898.

I'm putting this toward paying for the course so
£14,000 - £3,898 = £10,102

The remaining cost are
£10,102 + £13,014.85 = £23,116.85 = $35,442.75

I'm asking for $40,000 to cover the price of the plane ticket and Indiegogo's cut.

ARE WE READY FOR THE PERKS???
-YEAH YOU ARE!

Besides my deepest gratitude, there will be tangible thank you gifts. I am not much of a social networker, but I understand I'm not doing this alone even if I'm the only one going to London. Every person that helps is there with me and I want to show my appreciation and share my journey with them. Therefore, on my Actor's Business page I will have a cover photo and you will be included in it. There are personalized E-cards, Thank You Cards, Follow up emails (with photos) about my experience AND an invitation to join me for a going away get together with my closests friends/family.

WHAT HAPPENS IF.......

If I do not reach my goal:

Indiegogo allows me to keep the money I raised even if I don't reach the fundraising goal so your gift will help with the cost no matter what.

The first thing the money I raise will go to is towards housing, this is because RADA offers a payment plan that spreads the cost over the length of the program. I will be working so I hope to be able to pay it with my wages.

SO YOUR MONEY IS NOT WASTED! It will help to provide me with a roof over my head.

The Impact

The impact of Art is hard to define and the impact of an artist, of helping someone become a better artist, is even harder. I believe that Art can bring people together by reminding us of our essential nature, which I believe tends toward compassion, kindness and love. A great work of Art can break through the crust of everyday life with all of its fears, worries and tensions and open us to a deeper, truer reality. We can find ourselves, our real selves which then can open us to the possibility of change.

A work of Art can't cure a disease, stop a war, or heal the planet but if it can open the heart of even one person to his or her essential self then maybe that person can go out and effect some positive change in our world.

I want to be the kind of artist that has the ability to break through the crust of our daily lives and open up to a deeper reality. I know the ability to do this is the work of a lifetime, but I believe this program at RADA is an important step to getting me there. But I need your help to get there.

Art enables us to find ourselves and lose ourselves at the same time.
Thomas Merton

Art is the only way to run away without leaving home.
Twyla Tharp

The essence of all beautiful art, all great art, is gratitude.
Friedrich Nietzsche
Other Ways You Can Help

You can contribute in many ways!

If it isn't the right time to give financially, DO NOT FRET!,you can still support by telling your friends and family and definitely coworkers about this campaign. Maybe they can help.

From the bottom of my heart, thank you in advance!
Marguerite

story:
What is The Olio?

Coming soon to Winston-Salem, North Carolina, The Olio plans to be open for full programs by Fall 2013!

Located in the new re-development project called West End Mill Works, The Olio will be a HOT GLASSBLOWING STUDIO, ARTS APPRENTICE PROGRAM for local YOUTH ages 14-20, a Gallery and retail operation, Artist Mentorship Program, Business Incubator Program and many other community programs all highlighting our core values: ARTS, EDUCATION, COMMUNITY, and SUSTAINABILITY.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need your help! We have a solid plan and a great revenue stream once we are open; however all the planning in the world doesn't change the fact that we are not able to fund this program by ourselves. We have two campaigns planned, the first one is only 60 days and we need to raise $150,000 to start ordering equipment and pay for our share of the construction. That's a lot of money and not much time, but we are confident that you, our community, will be excited enough to get us there and in time!

In total we need $350,000 to build a state of the art studio, complete with UL certified (safe and secure!) equipment built right here in North Carolina by Wet Dog Glass. Construction began January 2, 2013 and we are optimistic we will be moved in by mid-year. We are starting our fundraising with this indiegogo campaign for $150,000, as we will seek funding through numerous channels.

 

We have made a few sample perks in our home studio while we wait for the construction to finish at the hot shop, but the bulk of them will be made in the fall when we are open so please be patient!

 

 

 

 

 

Here is a photo of the keychains, feel free to specify which color family you want, like blues, greens, etc..we will do our best to send you one you will love! 

 

 

 

 

 

 

These glasses were made from glass bottles with enamel labels. Thanks to Markus Parker for making the samples for us! And please get in touch if you have empty bottles for us, we have already started collecting them!

 

 

 

Don't forget, all our products are made from recycled and repurposed materials!

 

For example...these coasters are ceramic tile leftover from our in-laws' bathroom, magazine covers, fabric and glue! They are all unique and a definite conversation piece!

 

*all images by Sally Gupton Photography 

 

Please, please consider sharing your generosity with the The Olio and our wonderful programs for kids, families, adults, you. $5, $50, $5000....every penny will go towards the purchase of glass equipment, construction, ventilation and the glass studio that will be an exciting and fun place for you to enjoy.

The Olio is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization, so all donations are tax-deductible. We are also applying for grants, foundation contributions, corporate sponsorship and various other funding sources.  Please do not hesitate to contact us if you have a desire to contribute separate from this indiegogo campaign. 

We want our community, local and online, to participate and show the world that this is a great approach to arts education and entrepreneurship! Our first campaign is quick - 60 days to raise $150,000 and we think we can do it!

 

How Does This Affect You?

By participating in this fundraising effort you are investing in your own enjoyment and future. If you are local you can take a workshop, buy a unique gift, watch live glassblowing, be an apprentice, mentor, incubated business...or if you are online you can purchase work made by apprentices in our online store, watch videos of glassblowing, design your own piece via skype! There many ways for people to participate in art-making and entrepreneurship, we are eager to open and show you all of our plans.

This space, this program, will not only bring hot glass to the Triad, it will bring about an exciting, fun and effective way to teach entrepreneurship, sustainability, and community. We look forward to sharing it with you!

Don't Forget To

  • Share our posts on social media
  • Collect bottles, donate materials and supplies, volunteer your time or expertise
  • Send this video + campaign to everyone you know! Please :)
  • Consider hosting a casual informative event to help connect interested people
  • Sign up for our mailing list at www.theolio.com

 

 

Eternal thanks to Blake Faucette, StarWorksNC, Sally Gupton Photography, Chris Jacques, and Wet Dog Glass...without whom none of this would be possible.

What is The Olio?
Coming soon to Winston-Salem, North Carolina, The Olio plans to be open for full programs by Fall 2013!
Located in the new re-development project called West End Mill Works, The Olio will be a HOT GLASSBLOWING STUDIO, ARTS APPRENTICE PROGRAM for local YOUTH ages 14-20, a Gallery and retail operation, Artist Mentorship Program, Business Incubator Program and many other community programs all highlighting our core values: ARTS, EDUCATION, COMMUNITY, and SUSTAINABILITY.
 


What We Need & What You Get
We need your help! We have a solid plan and a great revenue stream once we are open; however all the planning in the world doesn't change the fact that we are not able to fund this program by ourselves. We have two campaigns planned, the first one is only 60 days and we need to raise $150,000 to start ordering equipment and pay for our share of the construction. That's a lot of money and not much time, but we are confident that you, our community, will be excited enough to get us there and in time!
In total we need $350,000 to build a state of the art studio, complete with UL certified (safe and secure!) equipment built right here in North Carolina by Wet Dog Glass. Construction began January 2, 2013 and we are optimistic we will be moved in by mid-year. story:
Inner Peace for Inner Tough is an interactive book project that will become the Training Manual for Health Practitioners and Trainers to use for clients suffering from chronic stress disorder.


This project starts with 3 individuals ( A Navy Veteran, A Cancer Survivor and a Single Mom ) and documents the training process used for chronic stress management.

At the end of this particular project we will implement Tai Chi classes in Las Vegas, Memphis, San Diego and Phoenix.

I decided to launch this campaign because  I wanted to show people that Tai Chi is not just for old people in the park.  No matter what kind of stress you are facing, you can learn to navigate through it in a loving way. Learning the movement in Zen Method Tai Chi changes your body and thoughts.  I believe chronic low level stress is a silent killer. The people included in this project have families that need them. They are advocates in a society that needs them to continue important work. They have children that are looking up to them. By setting the example of health and happiness in their lives, they are creating healthy lifestyles for generations to come.


The three individuals chosen will be personally trained by me to learn how to effectively deal with chronic stress. In that process, I will be training them how to become an Instructor as well so they will be able to continue the work and share what they have learned for years to come.

My name is Angella Hamilton.  I am the Creator and Founder of the Inner Peace for Inner Tough Project. I have spent the last 8 years helping clients reduce stress and build strength.  You can find out more about me at http://zenmethodtaichi.com.


What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for $3,000.00 for this campaign for the initial training phase for each participant.  Because each person has such different needs, they will collectively need over 120 hours of training to fully understand and be able to teach a class upon completion.

We have an account manager who is the Treasurer of a National Non-profit Organization to oversee the project budget and to track our contribution incomes and project payables. She has agreed to donate much of her time, but overall, it will be about 10% of the money raised.

The bulk of the money will go toward the training expenses for facilities, photo and video of the process, and the hiring of Co-Trainers to work with the individuals when I am not on the scene.

If we do not raise the full amount, we will still use the money for all of the above, just on a limited basis and not the full Training module.

Ways You Can Help

We understand not everyone can contribute, but please, share this campaign with everyone you know. At the very least, go to the http://zenmethodtaichi.com and download the free report so you can have Inner Peace for yourself.  And watch us! Watch how the story unfolds on Facebook at Inner Peace for Inner Tough and read our blog. It is a story of life and recapturing the spark that sometimes needs a little rekindling.

Thank you for taking the time to consider this Campaign.

With deep, sincere gratitude,

Angella M. Hamilton

story:
Short Summary

Hi! My name is Kjerstin, and I need help graduating from Arizona State University!  Last semester was supposed to be my final semester.  I was excitedly preparing to move on to the next phase of my life: pursuing a graduate degree in ministry.  Unfortunately, I received some bad advice from my advisor and found out too late that I would need to take one more class!  Tuition at ASU is astronomical.  Just one class, three measly credit hours, is $2,125! This doesn't include the cost of books and many of the other fees!

What We Need & What You Get

I need about $3000.  I can pay it in three chunks, but the more i can pay now, the better. Any money that you so graciously donate will go directly towards paying for this class.

The Impact

After I finish this class, I will finally be able to graduate with a B.A. in Literature.  Once I graduate from ASU, I plan to go to Seminary and get a degree in Children's Ministry.  I am passionate about loving children and buidling them up to be healthy individuals.  By helping me graduate from ASU, you will be helping me get one step closer to realizing my dream!  Thank you so much!

story:
Our History

Pastoralist Child Foundation was founded in August, 2012 when Sayydah Garrett, a teacher from New Jersey, went on a safari to Samburu and Maasai Mara, Kenya to see the big 5 and annual migration of beautiful animals. It was an incredible 2-week experience that changed her life forever. The itinerary included a visit to a tribal village called  "Namayiana" in Samburu. The villagers are pastoralists - a semi-nomadic tribe who mainly herd cattle, goats and sheep. Back at the lodge, Sayydah showed her  pictures to the restaurant captain, Samuel Siriria Leadismo.  He knew everyone in the pictures because he's from Namayiana Village!  After several minutes, Samuel became serious and said, "I want to start an organization to eradicate FGM (female genital mutilation/cutting) and forced marriages of girls before it's my youngest sister's turn to get cut. Girls should go to school and get an education."  Sayydah offered to help from 7,500 miles away in New Jersey. Samuel smiled and said, "Great! You will be our President!" and Sayydah replied, "Ok!"  Two complete strangers spiritually believed that there was a more profound purpose for the African safari.  Samuel is the very first Samburu Warrior in history to found an organization to eradicate FGM and forced marriages. We're so honored to have him as our Founder & Director of Samburu Circuit!  

The following week, Sayydah continued on safari to Maasai Mara and became instant friends with Joyce Nashipae Koitumet, a receptionist at the eco-tented camp. She, too, offered to help and is our Founder & Director of Maasai Mara Circuit. 

We recently celebrated our first year anniversary as a nonprofit! The journey is so exciting as we continue to network and partner with other like-minded individuals and organizations around the world.  The encouragement and support of our friends and donors keep us going, as do the people in the communities we serve. They're our biggest cheerleaders!


Sayydah with her new friends at Namayiana Village, Samburu, Kenya

 

What We Need & Your Impact

To date, we've sponsored 6 girls in primary and secondary boarding schools in Samburu and Maasai Mara. Our goal is to sponsor 30 more girls in 2014. In addition, we will start our community mobilization, sensitization and educational programs on the harmful effects of FGM and childhood marriage, HIV/AIDS prevention, teen pregnancy and child rights. The workshops are for children, teens, adults and elders.  Activities will include plays & drama, video presentations, public barazas, and village visits. We'll implement safe and fun Alternative Rites of Passage where girls will attend secluded and uninterrupted retreats to learn about sexual reproduction, reproductive health, family life skills, and personal hygiene, followed by a community-wide celebration for the abandonment of FGM. Time is of the essence! The next round-up of girls for circumcision ceremonies is in August during school holidays. Here's what the girls are NOT looking forward to: FGM Facts Female Genital Mutilation is illegal in every country around the world. Yet, it is openly and oftentimes secretly performed on innocent girls as young as 5 years old.  This is downright horrific, especially when young girls are prevented from attending school because they're forced to get married. This just doesn't make sense in our day and age when all girls, no matter where they live or their families' financial circumstances, should be allowed to go to school.  Pastoralist Child Foundation alligns with the United Nations Millennium Development Goals. These goals state that every child in the world should have access to education by the year 2015. We're deeply committed to this goal and it's time for action.

Quality girls’ education empowers by giving them choices, alleviates poverty and yields great returns in socio-economics, health, population and politics. Girls’ education leads to increased income for girls themselves, but also for nations as a whole. Better educated girls become women who have smaller, healthier families with lower infant mortality rates, and maternal mortality. Primary education significantly helps reduce infant mortality, and secondary education helps even more because women know how to use health services, improving nutrition and sanitation, and taking advantage of their own increased earning capability. In addition, girls who get a quality education marry later when they’re better able to bear and care for their children.

Your support will make a huge impact by educating the overall community to support the acceleration of the abandonment of FGM and foster positive gender attitudes among girls.   

Funds raised in this campaign will be used to produce educational materials to assist in the program. We'll identify 120 activists, law enforcers, circumcisers and cultural custodians to attend 3-day training workshops. The 2014 goal is to decrease instances of FGM by 21%.  Together we can do this!!

By financially supporting Pastoralist Child Foundation, you're making history by improving the educational and living standards of the beautiful Samburu and Maasai tribes. If all goes well and we raise our goal of $20,000 you will rescue 50 girls from undergoing FGM. If we exceed our goal, your impact will be even greater - giving more girls access to a formal education. We promise you that 100% of all donations from this Indiegogo campaign will go towards our educational programs.        


Christine, Carolyne and Ann are starting high school in January, 2014.

A sponsorship of $1,200 pays for an entire year of private boarding school.


Brenda is our first sponsored student! Here she is on her first day of school, accompanied by Pastoralist Child Foundation's Founder & Director of Samburu Circuit, Samuel Siriria Leadismo.


                

Meet Janet, a grade 9 student sponsored by Pastoralist Child Foundation. She's starting high school in January, 2014. Janet is an extremely grateful young lady and has many ideas about the path she would like to take in order to help her family and community. 


Pastoralist Child Foundation Founder & Director of Samburu Circuit, 

Samuel Siriria Leadismo (back row left) and our wonderful volunteer mentors at a recent meeting in Samburu. We are grateful for our mentors who are so caring and committed to helping our girls succeed!  

Your Perks!

Shuka blankets are very warm and are traditionally worn by  men. There are many other uses for them:  fashionable wrap, couch throws, picnic blankets, bed covers, table cloths, curtains - use your imagination!  

------------------------------------------------------------


                       

Maasai beaded bracelets come in all different colors. Tell us your favorite color and we'll do our best to match it.  

-----------------------------------------------------------                                      


     Beautiful Maasai beaded keychain

------------------------------------------------------------


              

      Pastoralist Child Foundation natural           ingredients cherry-flavored lip balm. 

------------------------------------------------------------

What you can do - Invest in the future!

You can help us realize our dream of educating girls and their respective communities by doing the following for us:

  • Donate what you can - every little bit helps.  We welcome your charitable contributions for this year and pledge to put them to good use. To our friends in the European Union and Canada, you can donate in your currencies now....the Euro and Canadian Dollar...nice & easy!
  • Share our IndieGoGo fundraising link with your social networks.
  • Ask your employer to match your donation through the Employee Gift Matching Program.
  • Make a donation in honor or memory of a friend or loved-one who values education. How about your favorite teacher, professor or parents who have installed the love of education in you?
  • Ask your loved-ones for a donation in your name to Pastoralist Child Foundation.
  • Subscribe to our newsletter to stay informed about our activities.
  • Indiegogo online donations are very safe. However, if you're not comfortable with donating online, you're welcome to mail a check to: Pastoralist Child Foundation, 51 Clark Street, Glen Ridge, NJ 07028 USA

       Thank you for joining us in this effort! Peace and Blessings!

             All donations to Pastoralist Child Foundation are tax-deductible.

                                                 (tax ID #46-2346090)

story:
Short Summary

My name is Arielle, but my students know me as Ms. Starkman...or even just Miiiissss (when they are hollering for me from across the room).  I am the teacher of an elementary special education class in a heavily impoverished and impacted part of the city of Los Angeles, called Koreatown.  My school, the New Open World Academy is a unique entity in Los Angeles Unified School District. We are a Kindergarten through 12th grade, Title 1, span school where 88% of students are economically disadvantaged.  My students are in grades 2, 3, and 4 and have mild to moderate learning disabilities and autism.  I teach a self-contained, multi-level special education class, which means that all of my students are with me in our class for the greater part of the school day. The majority of my 2nd, 3rd, and 4th grade students currently read at Pre-Kindergarten and Kindergarten reading levels.  Although my students have already fallen behind in reading, they enjoy reading and are excited to learn.  Their eagerness to become better readers is extremely inspirational to me.  I am thankful to have such a driven class of young scholars who persevere, even when their disabilities set them back. Seeing their ten, smiling, little faces, jumping up and down shouting, "Good Morning Ms. Starkman!" every morning when I pick them up,  is what makes my 6:15 alarm every bit worth it!  I am asking for your support in funding the purchase of intensive reading intervention materials for my students.  I truly believe that each one of my students is an incredibly capable and intelligent, young individual.  The sky is the limit for these little guys. Closing the gaps they are currently experiencing in reading, will severely change the course of the remainder of their educational careers and far beyond.  I firmly believe that LITERACY is the key to a successful LIFE!

What We Need & What You Get

I have some lofty goals for my students and myself this year. All of my students will leave my class as readers in June.  All of my students will raise their current reading levels not just by a year, but by a year and a half. Although they are only 7, 8, 9, and 10 years old, I know that their success as middle schoolers, as high schoolers, and in their futures as adults, rests this year in my hands.  When students move up to the next grade without having made adequate reading progress, their gap only grows and playing the game of catch up will continue to get harder and harder.  

I would like to ask for your support in my campaign to provide my students with high quality literacy intervention materials.  It is my goal to provide each of my students with access to an online reading intervention program, called Reading Eggs.  This software provides students with highly interactive and individualized reading coaching and progress monitoring.  Students are given an assessment to determine their current ability level and are placed on a personalized path of instruction based on sequential literacy stages. I was fortunate to gain access to a 1 month trial of this Reading Eggs program at the beginning of November and it has been incredibly well received by my students.  As a result of this program, I have noticed my students' interest in reading, and their engagement in literacy based tasks grow tremendously. My students who have previously avoided any type of reading activity, now come in in the morning asking, "When are we going to use Reading Eggs?." Some, have even been known to chant, "Reading Eggs, Reading Eggs" throughout the day. I have witnessed my most struggling student, gain confidence in his reading ability. In the last few weeks, he has begun to volunteer to read aloud to the class for the first time!  Unfortunately, our free class trial to reading eggs is almost up, and in order for my kids to continue strengthening their reading skills, we need your help.

Although literacy is the focal point in my class, I have noticed that handwriting is also an area of need for my students.  With our primary focuses being reading and math intervention, handwriting instruction is an area of need that we struggle to fit in during the school day.  Handwriting Without Tears is a way for students to work independently to improve their handwriting.  This program (that is geared specifically to students with special needs) works with students to improve the legibility of their writing through repetitive practice writing high frequency words.  I am asking for your help in funding the purchase of Hand Writing Without Tears workbooks for each of my students as well.

Any additional funds raised beyond my goal, will go towards funding educational field trips for my students, as well as purchasing additional reading, writing, and math intervention materials for our classroom.

In this season of thanks, I just want it thank each of you for your immense support. I believe we can all be a pivotal part of educating our next generation of citizens.  My students and I are grateful for any size donation you are able to contribute towards our classroom.   As an educator, I am thankful for my ten little "buddies" that have come into my life this school year.  These wonderful little children give me a purpose everyday and help keep my passion for education always ignited.

The Impact

After studying elementary and special education at the University of Delaware, I moved to Los Angeles as part of the Teach For America program in June of 2012.  I was hired as a high school special education teacher at the New Open World Academy in our fully inclusive secondary program.  The expectation was for me to support my high school students in being successful in their general education classes, to aid them in fulfilling the state and district's requirements necessary for high school graduation. But what no one told me when I was hired, was that my students lacked almost entirely every pre-requisite skill necessary to be truly successful. Most shocking to me was finding out that my students were reading at elementary reading levels.  The majority of my students in grades 9 through 12 were reading last year at about a 3rd Grade level, and my eldest student, a 19 year old and 5th year senior (who was just 3 years younger than myself) was reading at a Pre-Kindergarten level.  Although their skill sets were more or less the same as the elementary students I worked with during my student teaching, the students I was now charged to work with, were just a mere year or two away from "graduation."  For many months, I remained truly baffled. How could almost 12 years in the public education system have failed these students, MY students, so dramatically?

Before I began my work in Los Angeles, the "achievement gap" was only a hypothetical term to me. How could there really be so much inequity in public education?  How could such a glorified city like Los Angeles really be home to this? Although LA is a city of pristine beaches, luxury cars, hollywood film sets, and fine shopping and dining, it is also a city of tremendous and extreme economic disparity. Street to street, block to block, zip to zip, the economic disparity is ever present, ever raging, and ever ravishing. Individual, wealthier municipalities exist throughout the city, many with their own school districts. Weaving in and out of these municipalities, starting and stopping, chopping streets in half, is the city of Los Angeles.  To live in Los Angeles and have a Los Angeles zip code means that your children are automatically students of America's second largest school district, Los Angeles Unified.  For more fortunate families, living within LAUSD boundaries more than likely means that your children will become students of elite private schools.

As a special education teacher in Los Angeles, I am charged with providing the students who are considered to be the, "gap within the gap," with a high quality education. I wake up everyday to work towards closing the overwhelming gap that exists simply within the special education population in this urban community.  The disparity between the performance of students with disabilities and the performance of their general education peers is the "gap within the gap." 

How do we explain why high school students in this community, that have been classified as having mild learning disabilities, are still unable to read independently?  How is it that these students are still not able to correctly distinguish between short and long vowel sounds when asked to read words "The Crucible" or "Fahrenheit 451?" How is it that many of these high school students still need to be reminded regularly to start their sentences with a capital letter and end them with a punctuation mark?  If we are attributing their tremendous gaps in achievement to a "learning disability," then how can it be that all of the students who had learning disabilities from my own New Jersey high school, ended up graduating high school on time and pursuing their bachelors degrees at competitive universities?  If the reason these students cannot read is just because of their, "learning disabilities," then why is it that my overpriced college textbooks didn't define learning disabilities as something so debilitating, that it would prevent you from meeting high school graduation requirements? OBVIOUSLY THERE IS SOMETHING MUCH BIGGER GOING ON HERE.

My experience teaching high school last year,  left me feeling empowered to be proactive in making a difference in how we educate our elementary students with learning disabilities, so they too, do not end up as functionally illiterate high schoolers.  Too often in special education, we are forced to be reactive. Our students' gaps manage to grow so big that we are constantly trying to feed them the knowledge they need just to "catch up" or "get by."  Our goal becomes simply for them not to sink.  By doing this however, we are only facilitating the growth of their achievement gaps because we are not helping students to build up their basic skills.  We are teaching them to hold their head above water, instead of how to swim.  As special educators, we need to be proactive in preventing this game of catch up from ever starting.  This is exactly what I intend to do as an elementary special education teacher. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to donate to my campaign at this time, it doesn't mean you can't help!  It is my hope that you will be able to help me get the word out about my campaign by sharing it within your own network.  Please share this link as well as my campaign information with others via email, your Facebook profile, and in conversation.  Thank you again for your continued support of my students!

story:
Short Summary

We live in a place where literally every penny makes a HUGE difference in the lives of some of the world’s most underprivileged and marginalized children.  By making a donation of any amount, you stand strong with us and others around the world with loving hearts who believe that even though no one can do everything, everyone can do something.  It truly is amazing how much can be achieved with just a small amount of money from compassionate people like you and a helping hand from us.

Lvea village is Pagna’s home village.  He was born and raised there and they want him back!  Word has spread of Pagna’s success with teaching English to the children of Kampong Phluk and the community of Lvea Village has been pleading with him to return home and open a school.

In December of 2013 we set up a temporary school under Pagna's father's house in Lvea Village. Within three days 152 children enrolled!  Pagna teaches them in five classes per day, five days per week. While teaching the children outside isn't optimal, it is doable during the dry season. In June when the monsoon season begins, teaching the children outside will not be possible.  Pagna's father's house is too small and too old to support the weight of the students so teaching the children inside the house is not an option. That's where you come in!

What We Need & What You Get

Here are some of the costs we're looking at to get started:

- $9,000 for new building measuring 15 meters by 4 meters (approx. 49ft by 13ft)  which would include a classroom, a computer room, a room to house a Western volunteer teacher, two bathrooms for the children and a small library.  The building would be made of concrete and have a metal roof so it could easily withstand many years of monsoon season.

- $400  covers the cost of desks/chairs for the classroom and computer room.

- $150 to dig a well.

If we don't reach our goal of $9550.00 we will start with a smaller building, perhaps just a classroom, and build according to available funds.

If we exceed our goal we will put the money toward these items:

-$325 for supplementary workbooks for the children

- scholarships for our kids who want to further their education by attending University or vocational training.  Costs vary according to programs. 

- $2300 gets us five laptop computers and a printer/copier.

- $2000 for two solar units to power lights for the evening classes and to provide power for the computers.

If we further exceed our goal we would like to build a daycare center for younger children. All too often when both parents need to work the slightly older children have to stay home and take care of the younger children. We would prefer they come to class!

A daycare center would give us the opportunity to start enriching the cognitive development of the children at an earlier age and would also provide jobs for some of the women in the village.

The Impact

In 2010 Pagna began teaching free English classes to the children of Kampong Phluk.  He believes every child should have the opportunity to learn English and to get an education as this is their only hope of living more prosperous lives.   By learning English the children can secure jobs in the tourism/hospitality industry, thereby lifting themselves out of poverty.

When he began, Pagna had no school to teach in so he taught in his house during the wet season and under his house during the dry season. Thanks to the generosity of tourists passing by he was able to supply pencils and notebooks to the children.  Eventually a whiteboard, some desks and chairs were donated.  Today over 120 children are taught English at Pagna Language School KP in five classes per day, seven days per week.

Our mission is to provide a safe, fun, supportive environment where education and self-empowerment are of supreme importance. It is our goal to reduce impoverishment of the young and underprivileged in Cambodia and to enable them to create futures born of their dreams rather than live lives dictated by poverty. We aim to enable the children to overcome seemingly insurmountable odds in a holistic and sustainable way by providing them with the knowledge, skills and support they need to achieve economic independence and actively participate in their communities in positive and lasting ways.

None of this would be possible without the support of you – our volunteers, donors, supporters and friends who believe in our goal of awakening in each child the opportunity for a more meaningful and prosperous life. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Anyone and everyone can make make an impact.

  • Make some noise about our project: like us on Facebook and tell everyone you know about our campaign.
  • Please also use the Indiegogo share tools.
  • Volunteer at our schools! Check out the volunteer page on our website and come give us a hand teaching the children.

Thank you, to each and every one of you for taking the time to read about our project!
